RuleInstance.Name: Error handling -> Always define a global error handler
RuleInstance.Title: Always define a global error handler
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Global.asax file does not contain global error handler.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Global error handler in Global.asax file should always be defined. It will allow to recover from an unhandled exception that occured in the current ASP.NET application.

Having a global error handler enables you to implement a common error recovery strategy for the entire application and and saves you from trapping the Error event in each page.

The code inside the Error event handler can access all the usual properties in the Request object, what helps to find the source of the problem, and the methods of the Response object, which allow sending an alternative error message.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add global error handler.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Always define a global error handler.

RuleInstance.Name: Expression -> Avoid the DataBinder.Eval method
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid the DataBinder.Eval method
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: System.Web.UI.DataBinder.Eval method is invoked.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Avoid using System.Web.UI.DataBinder.Eval method. It uses reflection and, therefore, is slower than strong-typed access.

Cast the Container.DataItem object to DataRowView object when binding to a DataSet, DataTable, or DataView, or cast to a DbDataRecord object if you are binding to a DataReader.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Modify your code manually to cast the Container.DataItem object to a specific object.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid the DataBinder.Eval method.

RuleInstance.Name: Expression -> Avoid the Page.DataBind method
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid the Page.DataBind method
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Page.DataBind method is invoked.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Avoid Page.DataBind method; instead, invoke the DataBind method for each control that you want to bind to its data source.

The page-level DataBind method must recursively call the DataBind method of all controls on the page.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Invoke the DataBind method for each control that you want to bind to its data source.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid the Page.DataBind method.

RuleInstance.Name: Server Controls -> Avoid setting the AutoPostBack property to True
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid setting the AutoPostBack property to True
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: AutoPostBack property of a server control is set to True.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription: The AutoPostBack feature relies on client-side JavaScript code; if a Web Forms page contains one or more controls whose AutoPostBack property is set to True and the user has disabled JavaScript support, the user has no means to submit the form unless you also provide one or more button controls.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Make sure that user can submit form if client-side JavaScript support is disabled.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid setting the AutoPostBack property to True.

RuleInstance.Name: MVC controller action -> Use ValidateAntiforgeryTokenAttribute
RuleInstance.Title: Use ValidateAntiforgeryTokenAttribute to protect against potential CSRF attacks in MVC controller action
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: MVC Controller action method does not contain System.Web.Mvc.ValidateAntiForgeryTokenAttribute but defined HttpVerbs.Post.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Rule that verifies that if the System.Web.Mvc.ValidateAntiForgeryTokenAttribute is used to protect against Potential CSRF attack in MVC.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'MarkVerbHandlersWithValidateAntiforgeryToken', CheckId CA5332
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add System.Web.Mvc.HttpGetAttribute to method
  • Add System.Web.Mvc.ValidateAntiForgeryTokenAttribute and System.Web.Mvc.HttpPostAttribute to method
  • Add System.Web.Mvc.HttpPostAttribute to method
  • Comment out System.Web.Mvc.HttpGetAttribute in method
  • Comment out System.Web.Mvc.ValidateAntiForgeryTokenAttribute in method
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Use ValidateAntiforgeryTokenAttribute to protect against potential CSRF attacks in MVC controller action.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Public Function SubmitUpdate() As ViewResult

  ...

End Function


' This is the correct implementation

<HttpPost> _
<ValidateAntiForgeryToken> _
Public Function SubmitUpdate() As ViewResult

  ...

End Function

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

public ViewResult SubmitUpdate()
{

  ...

}

// This is the correct implementation

[HttpPost]
[ValidateAntiForgeryToken]
public ViewResult SubmitUpdate()
{

  ...

}

RuleInstance.Name: Web.Config -> Form authentication SlidingExpiration should be False
RuleInstance.Title: Form authentication SlidingExpiration should be False in web.config
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: system.web.authentication.forms slidingExpiration should be set to false when the site is being serviced over HTTP.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The rule verifies that if the system.web.authentication.forms slidingExpiration be set to false when the site is being serviced over HTTP.
This will force the authentication cookie to have a fix timeout value instead of being refreshed by each request. Since the cookie will traverse over clear text network and can be sniffed, having a fix timeout value on the cookie will limit the amount of time the cookie can be replayed. If the cookie is traversing over HTTPS, it is less likely to be intercepted and having the slidingExpiration setting to True will cause the timeout to be refreshed after each request which gives a better user experience.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'FormAuthenticationSlidingExpirationShouldBeFalse', CheckId CA5406
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Set slidingExpiration attribute value of the system.web.authentication.forms element to false in web.config
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Form authentication SlidingExpiration should be False in web.config.

RuleInstance.Name: Web.Config -> Http runtime EnableHeaderChecking should be True
RuleInstance.Title: Http runtime EnableHeaderChecking should be True in web.config
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: system.web.httpRuntime.enableHeaderChecking attribute is disabled in web.config.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The rule verifies that the system.web.httpRuntime enableHeaderChecking attribute is set to true.
The setting indicates whether ASP.NET should check the request header for potential injection attacks. If an attack is detected, ASP.NET responds with an error. This forces ASP.NET to apply the ValidateRequest protection to headers sent by the client. If an attack is detected the application throws HttpRequestValidationException.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'HttpRuntimeEnableHeaderCheckingShouldBeTrue', CheckId CA5416
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Set enableHeaderChecking attribute value of the system.web.httpRuntime element to true in web.config
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Http runtime EnableHeaderChecking should be True in web.config.

RuleInstance.Name: Web.Config -> Page EnableViewStateMac should be True
RuleInstance.Title: Page EnableViewStateMac should be True in web.config

RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: system.web.pages.enableViewStateMac attribute is disabled in web.config.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
EnableViewStateMac attribute specifies whether ASP.NET should run a message authentication code (MAC) on the view state for the page when the page is posted back from the client. The directive should be set to True. If so, the encrypted view state is checked to verify that it has not been tampered with on the client.

RuleInstance.Name: MVC controller action -> Enable request validation

RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Make sure that the ValidateInputAttribute is used properly to protect against XSS attacks.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The rule verifies if the ValidateInputAttribute is used properly to protect against XSS attacks.
ValidateInputAttribute attribute can be used to mark action methods whose input must be validated.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'ControllerActionShouldValidateInput', CheckId CA5333
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Set ValidateRequestAttribute value to true.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Enable request validation in MVC controller action.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

<ValidateInput(False)> _
Public Function Create() As ActionResult

  ' Do something...

End Function


' This is the correct implementation

<ValidateInput(True)> _
Public Function Create() As ActionResult

  ' Do something...

End Function

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

[ValidateInput(false)]
public ActionResult Create()
{

  // Do something...

}

// This is the correct implementation

[ValidateInput(true)]
public ActionResult Create()
{

  // Do something...

}

RuleInstance.Name: Expression -> Do not use deprecated properties of Response object

RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The following properties of the Response object are deprecated and should not be used:
  • System.Web.HttpResponse.CacheControl (methods of System.Web.HttpCachePolicy class should be used instead).
  • System.Web.HttpResponse.Expires (methods of System.Web.HttpCachePolicy class should be used instead).
  • System.Web.HttpResponse.ExpiresAbsolute (methods of System.Web.HttpCachePolicy class should be used instead).
  • System.Web.HttpResponse.Buffer (System.Web.HttpResponse.BufferOutput property should be used instead).
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:

RuleInstance.Name: Expression -> Do not use SaveAs method to store uploaded files
RuleInstance.Title: Do not use SaveAs method to store uploaded files
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: System.Web.HttpPostedFile.SaveAs method is invoked.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Avoid using System.Web.HttpPostedFile.SaveAs method to store the incoming data to temporary files on the server's hard disk. Instead, read data from the incoming stream and save it directly to the appropriate data store, for example, a database.

The System.Web.HttpPostedFile.SaveAs method requires that you grant ASP.NET an identity with the permission to write to the server's hard disk.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Manually read data from the incoming stream and save it directly to the appropriate data store.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not use SaveAs method to store uploaded files.

RuleInstance.Name: Async Method -> Should have "Async" suffix
RuleInstance.Title: Async method should have "Async" suffix
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Abstract, Static, Virtual, Override
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Public method is marked as async modifier but does ends with an Async suffix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription: Initiation and completion of an asynchronous operation in the TAP are represented by a single method, and thus there is only one method to name. Asynchronous methods in the TAP are named with an Async suffix that follows the operation's name, e.g. MethodNameAsync. (If adding a TAP method to a class that already contains a method MethodNameAsync, the suffix TaskAsync may be used instead, resulting in MethodNameTaskAsync.)
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename code element MethodName and its references to MethodNameAsync.
  • Rename code element MethodName and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Async method should have Async suffix.

RuleInstance.Name: Async Method -> Should have await statement
RuleInstance.Title: Async method should have await statement
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Public method is marked as async but no await statement is found in its body.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription: If you call an API which returns a Task, you should almost always await it either immediately or later on or indirectly through something like Task.Wait. Compilers have a warning in some cases but not all.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Remove async modifier from the async method.
  • Add await statement to the async method manually.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Async method should have await statement.

RuleInstance.Name: Async Method -> Should return Task or Task<T>
RuleInstance.Title: Async method should return Task or Task<T>
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Public method is marked as async but return type is not System.Threading.Tasks.Task or System.Threading.Tasks.Task<T>
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription: In TAP the singular method returns either a Task or a Task<TResult>, based on whether the corresponding synchronous method would return void or a type TResult, respectively.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Specify Task or Task<T> return type for the method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Async methods should return Task or Task<T>.

RuleInstance.Name: Async Method -> Avoid "out" and "ref" parameters
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid "out" and "ref" parameters in async method
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Public method is marked as async has one or many out or ref parameters.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription: The parameters to a TAP method should be the same parameters provided to the synchronous counterpart, in the same order. However, out and ref parameters are exempted from this rule and should be avoided entirely. Any data that would have been returned through an out or ref parameter should instead be returned as part of the returned Task<TResult>'s Result, utilizing a Tuple or a custom data structure in order to accommodate multiple values.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Remove ref or out parameters from the method manually.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid "out" and "ref" parameters in async method

Async method is called but is not awaited with either:

RuleInstance.Name: Async Method -> Call Start on the Task
RuleInstance.Title: Call Start on the Task object before instantiating
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
Method returns Task which is not started with either:
  • Start
  • Task.Factory.StartNew
  • Task.Run
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription: All tasks that are returned from TAP methods must be activated. If a TAP method internally uses a tasks constructor to instantiate the task to be returned, the TAP method must call Start on the Task object before returning it. Consumers of a TAP method may safely assume that the returned task is active and should not try to call Start on any Task that is returned from a TAP method. Calling Start on an active task results in an InvalidOperationException exception.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Call Start on the Task object before instantiating manually.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Call Start on the Task object before instantiating

However, out and ref parameters are exempted from this rule and should be avoided entirely. RuleInstance.Name: Async Method -> Transform to non-async if simple
RuleInstance.Title: Transform simple async method to non-async
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Avoid single line If statement
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid single line If statement
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Method should not contain single-statement If block.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, it is recommended to avoid single-line If statements.

If statement should be always closed with an End If keyword (for C#, curly braces should be used for if blocks that contain single line). By doing so, it is easier to add comments and other statements later in the development and debugging process.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Split If block into a multiline statement.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid single line If statement.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

	' Violates the rule
	If x > 0 Then y = 0

' This is the correct implementation

	If x > 0 Then
	  y = 0
	End If

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

	// Violates the rule
	if (x > 0) y = 0;

// This is the correct implementation

	if (x > 0)
	{
	  y = 0;
	}

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Do not include multiple statements on a single line
RuleInstance.Title: Do not include multiple statements on a single line
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Method should not contain multiple statements on a single line.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, it is not recommended to include multiple statements on a single line.

Lines containing single statements make the code more readable and enable you to add a comment for each individual statement.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Split statements into multiple lines.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not include multiple statements on a single line.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

	' Violates the rule
	x = 1 : y = 2

' This is the correct implementation

	x = 1 ' separate comment for the statement
	y = 2 ' separate comment for the statement

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

	// Violates the rule
	x = 1; y = 2;

// This is the correct implementation

	x = 1; // separate comment for the statement
	y = 2; // separate comment for the statement

RuleInstance.Name: Abstract Class -> Should Not Have Constructors
RuleInstance.Title: Abstract types should not have public constructors
RuleInstance.Scope: Abstract
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: An abstract public class has a public constructor.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, an abstract class (MustInherit in Visual Basic) must have a constructor with protected scope.

The constructor in an abstract class is meant to be called by derived types only. Therefore, it should have protected visibility.

You must add an explicit protected constructor in an abstract class to keep the Visual Basic compiler from mistakenly creating a parameterless public constructor.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Abstract types should not have constructors', CheckId CA1012
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Search for constructor(s) and change one(s) modifier.
  • Remove modifier for the type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Abstract types should not have public constructors.

RuleInstance.Name: Assembly -> Should have strong names
RuleInstance.Title: Assemblies should have strong names
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: An assembly is not signed with a strong name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, assembly should always be signed with a strong name. This rule applies to both DLL and EXE executables.

This rule offers several long-term advantages:
  • you can register the assembly in the global assembly cache (GAC);
  • the .NET runtime can detect whether the assembly has been tampered with;
  • assemblies called by your assembly can check the caller's identity.
Finally, if you use the assembly in a Smart Client application, a strong name enables the administrator of the client computer to relax Code Access Security (CAS) policy for only that specific assembly (or for all assemblies from your company).

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Assemblies should have valid strong names', CheckId CA2210
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Create .snk key file and sign assembly with a strong name using System.Reflection.AssemblyKeyFileAttribute attribute.
  • Use existing .snk key file for signing assembly with a strong name using System.Reflection.AssemblyKeyFileAttribute attribute.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Assemblies should have valid strong names.

RuleInstance.Name: Abstract Class -> Should have at least one derived class
RuleInstance.Title: Abstract class should have at least one derived class
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: An abstract class should have at least one derived class.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Provide at least one concrete type that inherits from each abstract class that you ship.

Doing this helps to validate the design of the abstract class. For example, System.IO.FileStream is an implementation of the System.IO.Stream abstract class.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Comment out an abstract class.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Abstract class should have at least one derived class.

RuleInstance.Name: Interface methods -> Should be callable by child types
RuleInstance.Title: Interface methods should be callable by child types
RuleInstance.Scope: Private
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: An unsealed public type implements explicitly a method of a public interface and does not provide an alternative access to the base implementation of the method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
If a base type, which is not sealed and externally visible, explicitly implements an interface with nonpublic members, ensure that derived types can access and override these members.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not override operator equals on reference types', CheckId CA1033
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Mark a type as NotInheritable (sealed in C#)
  • Change method modifier to Protected Overridable (Visual Basic only)
  • Add a new method which is visible to derived types (C# only)
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Interface methods should be callable by child types.

RuleInstance.Name: Project -> Should have AssemblyInfo file
RuleInstance.Title: Project should have AssemblyInfo file
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any

RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
AssemblyInfo.vb (AssemblyInfo.cs in C#) file is created automatically when you create an application with Microsoft Visual Studio. AssemblyInfo file should contain all assembly-level attributes such as assembly identity attributes, informational attributes, assembly manifest attributes, and strong name attributes.

The rule was specially created to ensure that project contains AssemblyInfo file.

The rule provides the following auto-correct options:

RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Project should have AssemblyInfo file.

RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
AssemblyInfo.vb (AssemblyInfo.cs in C#) file is created automatically when you create an application with Microsoft Visual Studio. AssemblyInfo file should contain all assembly-level attributes such as assembly identity attributes, informational attributes, assembly manifest attributes, and strong name attributes.

The rule was specially created to ensure that all assembly-level attributes are placed in the AssemblyInfo file.

RuleInstance.Name: Interface -> Should have implementation

RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Provide at least one type that is an implementation of an interface.

Doing this helps to validate the design of the interface. For example, System.Collections.Generic.List<T> is an implementation of the System.Collections.Generic.IList<T> interface.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:

RuleInstance.Name: Public/Protected Instance Field -> Do not declare
RuleInstance.Title: Do not declare externally visible instance fields
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: An externally visible instance field declared in the public class.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, public instance fields should neve be defined. Private fields wrapped inside public properties should be used instead. Such approach will allow to validate the incoming value before it's assigned to the private field. Even if the validation of the value in the current class do not required, using a property enables inheritors to apply more restrictive validation criteria. Fields do not enable values validation.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not declare visible instance fields', CheckId CA1051
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change field modifier.
  • Create property from the field and set its modifier.
  • Create property from the field with name and modifier specified.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not declare externally visible instance fields.

RuleInstance.Name: Sealed Class -> Do not declare protected members
RuleInstance.Title: Do not declare protected members in sealed types
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A sealed (NotInheritable in Visual basic) public type declares a protected member.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, a field, a property or a method should not be made public if that is not necessary.

Inheriting class can access or override protected member of the base class. A class marked as sealed (NotInheritable in Visual basic) cannot be used as a base class i.e. it cannot be inherited. So protected methods on sealed types cannot be called.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not declare protected members in sealed types', CheckId CA1047
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change type to inheritable.
  • Change the member(s) access level to specified.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not declare protected members in sealed types.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Imports System

Public NotInheritable Class Sample
    
    ' Violates the rule
    Protected Sub SomeMethod()
    
      ...
      
    End Sub
   
End Class 


' This is the correct implementation

Imports System

Public NotInheritable Class Sample
    
    Public Sub SomeMethod()
    
      ...
      
    End Sub
   
End Class 

- Or -

Imports System

' NotInheritable modifier has been removed
Public Class Sample
    
    Protected Sub SomeMethod()
    
      ...
      
    End Sub
   
End Class

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

using System;

public sealed class Sample
{
    
    // Violates the rule
    protected void SomeMethod()
    {
    
      ...
      
    }
   
}


// This is the correct implementation

using System;

public sealed class Sample
{
    
    public void SomeMethod()
    {
    
      ...
      
    }
   
}

- Or -

Imports System

// sealed modifier has been removed
public class Sample
{
    
    protected void SomeMethod()
    {
    
      ...
      
    }
   
}

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Do not hide base class methods
RuleInstance.Title: Do not hide base class methods
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Type declares method with the same name and with the same number of parameters as one of its base methods.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
A method in a derived type hides an identically named method in a base type, when derived method has the same number of parameters and type of one of parameters is a base type of the corresponding parameter in the base method.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not hide base class methods', CheckId CA1061
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename the method and its references to the specified name.
  • Comment out the implementation of the method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not hide base class methods.

RuleInstance.Name: Public Class -> Do not override operator equals
RuleInstance.Title: Do not override operator equals on reference types
RuleInstance.Scope: Public
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A public or nested public reference type overloads the equality operator or System.Object.Equals method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Two references are equal only if they point to the same object. The default implementation of the equality operator is almost always correct for reference types.

If the reference type behaves like a built-in value type, then this rule can be excluded from the analysis.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not override operator equals on reference types', CheckId CA1046
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Comment out the implementation of the System.Object.Equals method.
  • Comment out the implementation of the equality operator.
  • Comment out the implementation of the System.Object.Equals method and the implementation of the equality operator.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not override operator equals on reference types.

RuleInstance.Name: Enumeration -> Underlying Type Should Be Int32
RuleInstance.Title: Enum underlying type should be Int32 or one of the CLS-compliant integral types.
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The underlying type of a public enumeration is not System.Int32 or one of the CLS-compliant integral types.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, System.Int32 should be used as a base type for the enumeration type.

For some specific reasons it may be necessary to use a nondefault base type. One of the CLS-compliant integral types, System.Byte, System.Int16, System.Int32, or System.Int64, should be used in that case. A non-CLS-compliant integral types such as System.UInt32, or System.UInt64 should never be used.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Enum Storage should be Int32', CheckId CA1028
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change the enumeration member type to System.Int32.
  • Change the enumeration member type to System.Int64.
  • Change the enumeration member type to System.Int16.
  • Change the enumeration member type to System.Byte.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Enum underlying type should be Int32 or one of the CLS-compliant integral types.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

    ' Violation: non-CLS-compliant integral type is used
    Public Enum Answer As SByte
      No = 0
      Yes = 1
      Unknown = 3
    End Enum

' This is the correct implementation

    Public Enum Answer As Integer
      No = 0
      Yes = 1
      Unknown = 3
    End Enum

- Or -

    ' System.Int32 used by default
    Public Enum Answer
      No = 0
      Yes = 1
      Unknown = 3
    End Enum

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

    // Violation: non-CLS-compliant integral type is used
    public enum Answer : sbyte
    {
      No = 0,
      Yes = 1,
      Unknown = 3
    }

// This is the correct implementation

    public enum Answer : int
    {
      No = 0,
      Yes = 1,
      Unknown = 3
    }

- Or -

    // System.Int32 used by default
    public enum Answer
    {
      No = 0,
      Yes = 1,
      Unknown = 3
    }

RuleInstance.Name: Finalize -> Type -> Implement Finalizer Correctly
RuleInstance.Title: Implement Finalizer Correctly
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
Finalize method is not implemented correctly. Some reasons for this problem are listed below:
  • Type derives from a type that implements the System.IDisposable interface and overrides a finalizer.
  • Type implements the System.IDisposable interface and has incorrect a destructor implementation.
  • Type implements the System.IDisposable interface and has incorrect a finalizer implementation.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, types exposing both the Finalize method and the System.IDisposable interface must adopt the recommended Dispose-Finalize pattern.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Implement IDisposable Correctly', CheckId CA1063
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Comment out destructor (finalizer) of the type, override (if needed) System.IDisposable.Dispose(Boolean) method and put the finalization snippet in the code path where disposing is False.
  • Find destructor and modify it so that it calls Dispose(False) and then returns.
  • Find finalizer and modify it so that it calls Dispose(False), calls base finalizer and then returns.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Implement Finalizer Correctly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
[Visual Basic]


' The following code shows Dispose-Finalize design pattern for a base class:

Public Class DisposableType
  Implements IDisposable

  ' Keep track of when the object is disposed.
  Protected disposed As Boolean = False

  ' This method disposes the base object's resources.
  Protected Overridable Sub Dispose(ByVal disposing As Boolean)
		SyncLock Me
      If Not Me.disposed Then
        If disposing Then
          ' Release disposable objects used by this instance here.
        
          ...
        
        End If
        ' Release unmanaged resources here.
      
        ...
      
        Me.disposed = True
      End If
    End SyncLock
  End Sub

  Public Sub Dispose() Implements IDisposable.Dispose
    Dispose(True)
    
    ' Unregister object for finalization
    GC.SuppressFinalize(Me)
  End Sub
  
  Protected Overrides Sub Finalize()
    Try
      Dispose(False)
    Catch
      ' Deal with errors or just ignore them
    Finally
      ' Invoke the base object's Finalize method
      MyBase.Finalize()
    End Try
  End Sub
  
End Class

' The following code shows Dispose-Finalize design pattern for derived class:

Public Class DerivedDisposableType
  Inherits DisposableType

  ' This method disposes the derived object's resources.
  Protected Overloads Overrides Sub Dispose(ByVal disposing As Boolean)
		SyncLock Me
      If Not Me.disposed Then
        If disposing Then
          ' Release disposable objects used by this instance here.
        
          ...
        
        End If
        ' Release unmanaged resources here.
      
        ...

        ' Call the base object's Dispose protected method.
        MyBase.Dispose(disposing)
      
      End If
    End SyncLock
  End Sub

  ' The derived class does not have a Finalize method
  ' or a Dispose method with parameters because it inherits
  ' them from the base class.
End Class

[C#]


// The following code shows Dispose-Finalize design pattern for a base class:

public class DisposableType: IDisposable
{

  // Keep track of when the object is disposed.
  protected bool disposed = false;

  // This method disposes the base object's resources.
  protected virtual void Dispose(bool disposing)
  {
		lock(this)
		{
      if (!this.disposed)
      {
        if (disposing)
        {
          // Release disposable objects used by this instance here.
        
          ...
        
        }
        // Release unmanaged resources here.
      
        ...
      
        this.disposed = true;
      }
    }
  }

  public void Dispose()
  {
    Dispose(true);
    
    // Unregister object for finalization
    GC.SuppressFinalize(this);
  }
  
  ~DisposableType()
  {
    Dispose(false);
  }
  
}

// The following code shows Dispose-Finalize design pattern for derived class:

public class DerivedDisposableType: DisposableType
{

  // This method disposes the derived object's resources.
  protected override void Dispose(bool disposing)
  {
    lock(this)
    {
      if (!this.disposed)
      {
        if (disposing)
        {
          // Release disposable objects used by this instance here.
        
          ...
        
        }
        // Release unmanaged resources here.
      
        ...

        // Call the base object's Dispose protected method.
        base.Dispose(disposing);
      
      }
    }
    
  }

  // The derived class does not have a Finalize method
  // or a Dispose method with parameters because it inherits
  // them from the base class.
}

RuleInstance.Name: Dispose -> Type -> Implement IDisposable correctly
RuleInstance.Title: Implement IDisposable Correctly
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
The System.IDisposable interface is not implemented correctly. Some reasons for this problem are listed below:
  • Type derives from type that implements the System.IDisposable interface and implements System.IDisposable interface repeatedly.
  • Type implements System.IDisposable interface and has Dispose() method with non Public modifier.
  • Type derives from type that implements the System.IDisposable and overrides Dispose() method.
  • Type implements the System.IDisposable interface and has incorrect Dispose() method implementation.
  • Type implements the System.IDisposable interface and has Dispose(Boolean) method with incorrect modifiers.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, types exposing both the Finalize method and the System.IDisposable interface must adopt the recommended Dispose-Finalize pattern.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Implement IDisposable Correctly', CheckId CA1063
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Remove System.IDisposable interface from the list of interfaces implemented by the type and add (if needed) overridden base class Dispose implementation (System.IDisposable.Dispose(Boolean)).
  • Find Dispose() method and change its modifier to Public
  • Remove overridden Dispose() method, add (if needed) overridden Dispose(Boolean) method and put the dispose snippet in the code path where disposing is True.
  • Modify Dispose() method so that it calls Dispose(True), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize() on the current object instance, and then returns.
  • Find Dispose(Boolean) method and change its modifier.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Implement IDisposable Correctly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
[Visual Basic]


' The following code shows Dispose-Finalize design pattern for a base class:

Public Class DisposableType
  Implements IDisposable

  ' Keep track of when the object is disposed.
  Protected disposed As Boolean = False

  ' This method disposes the base object's resources.
  Protected Overridable Sub Dispose(ByVal disposing As Boolean)
		SyncLock Me
      If Not Me.disposed Then
        If disposing Then
          ' Release disposable objects used by this instance here.
        
          ...
        
        End If
        ' Release unmanaged resources here.
      
        ...
      
        Me.disposed = True
      End If
    End SyncLock
  End Sub

  Public Sub Dispose() Implements IDisposable.Dispose
    Dispose(True)
    
    ' Unregister object for finalization
    GC.SuppressFinalize(Me)
  End Sub
  
  Protected Overrides Sub Finalize()
    Try
      Dispose(False)
    Catch
      ' Deal with errors or just ignore them
    Finally
      ' Invoke the base object's Finalize method
      MyBase.Finalize()
    End Try
  End Sub
  
End Class

' The following code shows Dispose-Finalize design pattern for derived class:

Public Class DerivedDisposableType
  Inherits DisposableType

  ' This method disposes the derived object's resources.
  Protected Overloads Overrides Sub Dispose(ByVal disposing As Boolean)
		SyncLock Me
      If Not Me.disposed Then
        If disposing Then
          ' Release disposable objects used by this instance here.
        
          ...
        
        End If
        ' Release unmanaged resources here.
      
        ...

        ' Call the base object's Dispose protected method.
        MyBase.Dispose(disposing)
      
      End If
    End SyncLock
  End Sub

  ' The derived class does not have a Finalize method
  ' or a Dispose method with parameters because it inherits
  ' them from the base class.
End Class

[C#]


// The following code shows Dispose-Finalize design pattern for a base class:

public class DisposableType: IDisposable
{

  // Keep track of when the object is disposed.
  protected bool disposed = false;

  // This method disposes the base object's resources.
  protected virtual void Dispose(bool disposing)
  {
		lock(this)
		{
      if (!this.disposed)
      {
        if (disposing)
        {
          // Release disposable objects used by this instance here.
        
          ...
        
        }
        // Release unmanaged resources here.
      
        ...
      
        this.disposed = true;
      }
    }
  }

  public void Dispose()
  {
    Dispose(true);
    
    // Unregister object for finalization
    GC.SuppressFinalize(this);
  }
  
  ~DisposableType()
  {
    Dispose(false);
  }
  
}

// The following code shows Dispose-Finalize design pattern for derived class:

public class DerivedDisposableType: DisposableType
{

  // This method disposes the derived object's resources.
  protected override void Dispose(bool disposing)
  {
    lock(this)
    {
      if (!this.disposed)
      {
        if (disposing)
        {
          // Release disposable objects used by this instance here.
        
          ...
        
        }
        // Release unmanaged resources here.
      
        ...

        // Call the base object's Dispose protected method.
        base.Dispose(disposing);
      
      }
    }
    
  }

  // The derived class does not have a Finalize method
  // or a Dispose method with parameters because it inherits
  // them from the base class.
}

RuleInstance.Name: Assembly -> Should have assembly version
RuleInstance.Title: Mark assemblies with assembly version
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: An assembly does not have one of the following attributes applied to it: System.CLSCompliantAttribute, System.AssemblyVersionAttribute, or System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisibleAttribute.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, an assembly should have the following attributes applied:
  • System.CLSCompliantAttribute: Mark the assembly with a System.CLSCompliantAttribute attribute in a class library project to ensure that all its types and members are compliant with the Common Language Specification (CLS) and can be called by any other .NET language.
  • System.AssemblyVersionAttribute: The version number concurs to create the strong name of an assembly. If System.AssemblyVersionAttribute attribute is omitted, the assembly has no version. If an asterisk ("*") is used in the version number, the version number will change each time the assembly is recompiled. The version number should be changed when a new version of the assembly is published.
  • System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisibleAttribute: Attribute controls accessibility of an individual managed type or member, or of all types within an assembly, to COM. Assemblies should explicitly indicate COM visibility. The contents of the assembly are visible to COM clients by default, if the attribute is not present.
This rule is similar to the following FxCop rules:
  • 'Mark assemblies with assembly version', CheckId CA1016
  • 'Mark assemblies with CLSCompliant', CheckId CA1014
  • 'Mark assemblies with ComVisible', CheckId CA1017
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Apply missing attribute to the assembly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties: • AttributeToCheck - Certain Attribute to be checked.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Mark assemblies with assembly version.
  • Mark assemblies with CLSCompliant
  • Mark assemblies with ComVisible
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

<Assembly:AssemblyVersion("1.2.*")>


' This is the correct implementation

<Assembly:AssemblyVersion("1.2.3.4")>

<Assembly:CLSCompliant(True)>

<Assembly:System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisible(False)>

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

[assembly:AssemblyVersion("1.2.*")]


// This is the correct implementation

[assembly:AssemblyVersion("1.2.3.4")]

[assembly:CLSCompliant(true)]

[assembly:System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisible(false)]

RuleInstance.Name: Public Type -> Nested types should not be visible
RuleInstance.Title: Nested types should not be visible
RuleInstance.Scope: Public
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Public type contains the nested public type that does not implement System.Collections.IEnumerator interface.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, private or internal (Friend in Visual Basic) scope qulifier should be used for nested types.

Nested types are useful for encapsulating private implementation details of the containing type and should not be externally visible. A type should be nested if it is used only by the type that encloses it; therefore, in most cases there is no reason for making the nested type public.

Exception: Nested enumerators and comparers can be given public scope.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Nested types should not be visible', CheckId CA1034
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change the nested type modifier.
  • Move the nested type from its parent type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Nested types should not be visible.

RuleInstance.Name: Type -> Contains only static members -> Should be sealed (NotInheritable)
RuleInstance.Title: Type that contains only static members should be sealed (NotInheritable)
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A sealed (NotInheritable for Visual Basic) modifier does not set for a public or protected type that contains static members only.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, a type that is not meant to be inherited should be marked with the sealed (C#) or NotInheritable (Visual Basic) modifier. If a type containing static members only, then it does not provide any functionality that can be overridden in a derived type; therefore, it is not designed to be inherited.

A sealed type performs slightly better because all its properties and methods are implicitly sealed and the compiler can often inline them.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Static holder types should be sealed', CheckId CA1052
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change type modifier to sealed (NotInheritable for Visual Basic).
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Type that contains only static members should be sealed (NotInheritable).

RuleInstance.Name: Type -> Contains only static members -> Should not have public or protected constructors
RuleInstance.Title: Type that contains only static members should not have public or protected constructors
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A public or nested public type contains static members only, but has a public or protected default constructor.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Creating an instance does not provide access to any of the type's members, if the type contains static members only. Calling static members does not require an instance of the type; therefore the constructor is unnecessary.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Static holder types should not have constructors', CheckId CA1053
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change constructor(s) modifier to Private.
  • Comment out constructor(s) in the type.

RuleInstance.Name: Dispose -> Type -> That owns disposable fields should be disposable
RuleInstance.Title: Types that own disposable fields should be disposable
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Type has an instance field that is the System.IDisposable type, but does not implement the System.IDisposable interface.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, the System.IDisposable interface should be implemented if a method in the type creates one or more instances of other disposable objects (a disposable object is an object that implements the System.IDisposable interface) and the method doesn't invoke the objects' Dispose method before returning to the caller. A class that declares a System.IDisposable field should implement the System.IDisposable interface, because it indirectly owns an unmanaged resources.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Types that own disposable fields should be disposable', CheckId CA1001
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Implement Dispose-Finalize pattern for the type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Types that own disposable fields should be disposable.

RuleInstance.Name: Dispose -> Type -> That owns unmanaged resources should be disposable
RuleInstance.Title: Types that own unmanaged resources should be disposable
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A type has unmanaged field, but does not implement the System.IDisposable interface.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
If a type has System.IntPtr, System.UIntPtr, and System.Runtime.InteropServices.HandleRef fields, than it most likely stores pointers to unmanaged resources. Such types should implement the System.IDisposable interface to allow callers to release allocated unmanaged resources.

Types must adopt the recommended Dispose-Finalize design pattern to implement the System.IDisposable interface and clean up unmanaged resources.

The recommended design pattern to clean up unmanaged resources is to provide both an implicit and an explicit means to free those resources using the System.Object.Finalize method and the System.IDisposable.Dispose method, respectively. that allocate unmanaged resources should implement IDisposable According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, the System.IDisposable interface should be implemented if a method in the type creates one or more instances of other disposable objects (a disposable object is an object that implements the System.IDisposable interface) and the method doesn't invoke the objects' Dispose method before returning to the caller. A class that declares a System.IDisposable field should implement the System.IDisposable interface, because it indirectly owns an unmanaged resources.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Types that own native resources should be disposable', CheckId CA1049
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Implement Dispose-Finalize pattern for the type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Types that own unmanaged resources should be disposable.

RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, the following too general exceptions should not be thrown:
  • System.ApplicationException
  • System.Exception
  • System.SystemException
These exceptions are too general and therefore cannot provide the user with the sufficient information.

The following special .NET exception types should be thrown by the common language runtime only:
  • System.ExecutionEngineException
  • System.IndexOutOfRangeException
  • System.NullReferenceException
  • System.OutOfMemoryException
This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not raise reserved exception types', CheckId CA2201

  • Change type of the exception to the specified type.

RuleInstance.Name: VB.NET Project -> Enforce Option Compare
RuleInstance.Title: Enforce Option Compare
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The Option Compare statement does not specified explicitly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The Option Compare statement declares the default comparison method to use when comparing string data. The Option Compare statement specifies the string comparison method (Binary or Text) for a class, module or structure. If an Option Compare statement is not included, the default text comparison method is Binary.

According to the coding guidelines and best practices for projects and solutions, the Option Compare statement should be explicitly specified.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Set compiler option and VS IDE default Option Compare
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties: • OptionUsage - Set desired value for this compiler option. Possible values: Binary (set by default), Text.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Enforce Option Compare.

RuleInstance.Name: VB.NET Project -> Enforce Option Explicit
RuleInstance.Title: Enforce Option Explicit
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The Option Explicit statement does not specified explicitly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The Option Explicit statement forces explicit declaration of all variables in a file. When Option Explicit appears in a file, you must explicitly declare all variables using the Dim or ReDim statements. If you attempt to use an undeclared variable name, an error occurs at compile time.

According to the coding guidelines and best practices for projects and solutions, the Option Explicit On statement should be explicitly specified. It will help to avoid incorrectly typing the name of an existing variable or to avoid confusion in code where the scope of the variable is not clear.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Set compiler option and VS IDE default Option Explicit
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Enforce Option Explicit.

RuleInstance.Name: VB.NET Project -> Enforce Option Strict
RuleInstance.Title: Enforce Option Strict
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The Option Strict statement does not specified explicitly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Visual Basic allows conversions of many data types to other data types. Data loss can occur when the value of one data type is converted to a data type with less precision or smaller capacity. A run-time error occurs if such a narrowing conversion fails. Option Strict ensures compile-time notification of these narrowing conversions so they can be avoided.

In addition to disallowing implicit narrowing conversions, Option Strict generates an error for late binding. An object is late bound when it is assigned to a variable that is declared to be of type Object.

According to the coding guidelines and best practices for projects and solutions, the Option Strict On statement should be explicitly specified, because Option Strict On provides strong typing, prevents unintended type conversions with data loss, disallows late binding, and improves performance.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Set compiler option and VS IDE default Option Strict
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Enforce Option Strict.

RuleInstance.Name: Visual Studio -> Windows Forms Designer -> Set options correctly
RuleInstance.Title: Set all Windows Forms Designer settings correctly
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Windows Forms Designer settings are incorrect.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
You can set preferences for all the forms and projects you work with in the Windows Forms Designer.

Grid Size - Sets the spacing, in pixels, between horizontal and vertical gridlines on the designer. The default size is 8, 8.

Show Grid - Specifies whether designers display the sizing grid. By default, the grid is on.

SnapToGrid - Determines whether designers will snap objects and controls to the grid. In other words, the resizing and movement of elements on the designer are constrained to the GridSize increment when this feature is turned on. Having SnapToGrid turned on makes it easier to line up the various aspects of the user interface precisely, but limits the freedom with which one can place controls. By default, SnapToGrid is turned on.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations: Specify Windows Forms Designer settings for the project.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Set all Windows Forms Designer settings correctly.

RuleInstance.Name: Type, Member -> Should have XML comments

RuleInstance.Targets: Class, Interface, Delegate, Struct, Enumeration, Module, Type, Method, Operator, Event, Property, Indexer, EnumerationItem, Constant, Field, Member

RuleInstanceProperty.Name: IntelliCommentTemplate
RuleInstanceProperty.Value:
<#@ template language="C#" #>
<#
	CodeElement codeElement = Context.CurrentCodeElement;
#>
/// <summary>
/// <#= codeElement.XmlComment.SummaryTagText #>	
/// </summary>
<#
	if(codeElement.HasTypeParameters) 
	{
		foreach(TypeParameter typeParameter in codeElement.TypeParameters) {
#>
/// <typeparam name="<#= typeParameter.Name #>"><#= typeParameter.XmlComment.TypeParamTagText #></typeparam>
<#
		}
	}
	
	if(codeElement.HasParameters) 
	{
		foreach(Parameter parameter in codeElement.Parameters) {
#>
/// <param name="<#= parameter.Name #>"><#= parameter.XmlComment.ParaTagText #></param>
<#
		}
	}
	
	if(codeElement.HasReturnType) {
#>
/// <returns><#= codeElement.XmlComment.ReturnsTagText #></returns>
<#			
	}
	
	if(codeElement.IsProperty) {
#>
/// <value><#= codeElement.XmlComment.ValueTagText #></value>
<#
	}	
	
	if(codeElement.IsMember) {
#>
/// <remarks></remarks>
<#
	}	
#>

RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Externally visible type or member does not have XML comments.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
XML comments should be used to document all public types and their public members in class libraries, Windows Forms control projects, and ASP.NET Web control projects.

XML comments have the following advantages:
  • XML documentation file can be easily generated, if enabled the XML Documentation File option on the Build page of the Project Properties dialog box. By deploying this file in the same directory as the DLL executable, developers using your types or controls can read your comments in Visual Studio .NET's Object Browser.
  • The NDoc can be used to create the technical documentation of the class library or control.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add XML Comment with IntelliComment content to the type.
  • Add XML Comment stub to the type or member.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties:
• EnforceCheckingAllProjects - Ignore 'XML Documentation' flag. Enforce the XML Comments rule on the entire project regardless of the 'XML documentation file' option setting.
  • IntelliCommentTemplate - T4 template for XML Comment with IntelliComment content. IntelliComments feature is based on the GhostDoc algorithm.
  • StubTemplate - XML Comment Stub Template. T4 template for XML Comment stub.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Externally visible types and members should have XML comments.

RuleInstance.Name: Expression -> Specify CultureInfo
RuleInstance.Title: Specify CultureInfo
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: There is an overload of the method with System.Globalization.CultureInfo or System.IFormatProvider parameter exists, but not called.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, the culture-specific information should be explicitly specified if it is possible.

If System.Globalization.CultureInfo or System.IFormatProvider parameter is not specified explicitly, then methods of .NET Framework classes use default culture and formatting and, therefore, may produce results that will be incorrect for your scenarios.

The following methods are ignored by the rule:
  • System.Activator.CreateInstance
  • System.Resources.ResourceManager.GetObject
  • System.Resources.ResourceManager.GetString
This rule is similar to the following FxCop rules:
  • 'Specify CultureInfo', CheckId CA1304
  • 'Specify IFormatProvider', CheckId CA1305
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Call appropriate overload of a method and pass System.Globalization.CultureInfo.CurrentCulture as an argument.
  • Call appropriate overload of a method and pass System.Globalization.CultureInfo.InvariantCulture as an argument.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties: • TypeName - System.Globalization.CultureInfo or System.IFormatProvider.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Specify CultureInfo.
  • Specify IFormatProvider.

RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: There is an overload of a method with System.StringComparison parameter exists, but it does not used.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, System.StringComparison parameter should be explicitly specified if it is possible.

The following System.String methods provide an overload with a System.StringComparison parameter:
  • System.String.Compare
  • System.String.EndsWith
  • System.String.Equals
  • System.String.IndexOf
  • System.String.LastIndexOf
  • System.String.StartsWith
You should always use an overload that accepts a System.StringComparison enumeration value as a parameter, if you use one of thee methods.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Specify StringComparison', CheckId CA1307
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Call appropriate overload of a method and pass System.StringComparison.CurrentCulture as an argument.
  • Call appropriate overload of a method and pass System.StringComparison.InvariantCulture as an argument.
  • Call appropriate overload of a method and pass System.StringComparison.Ordinal as an argument.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Specify StringComparison.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Avoid Long type arguments
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid Long type arguments for VB6 clients
RuleInstance.Scope: Public
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Type marked as COM visible and declares method that takes a System.Int64 argument.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, .NET components that are meant to be exposed to COM clients shouldn't use features that COM-based clients can't see. Or they should provide alternative ways for COM clients to accesss these features.

The class shouldn't expose methods or properties that take or return System.Int64 values because they can't be handled by Visual Basic 6 clients.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Avoid int64 arguments for VB6 clients', CheckId CA1406
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change parameter return type on System.Int32
  • Change parameter return type on System.Decimal
  • Add System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisibleAttribute attribute to the method and set it to False
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid Long type arguments for VB6 clients.

RuleInstance.Name: Non-public Field -> Avoid in ComVisible value types
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid non-public fields in ComVisible value types
RuleInstance.Scope: Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A Structure (struct in C#) that is specifically marked as visible to COM declares a non-public instance field.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
A non-public instance field, which is declared in the COM visible Structure (struct in C#), is visible to COM clients. Such field may expose sensitive data and cause security risks.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Avoid non-public fields in ComVisible value types', CheckId CA1413
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change the System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisibleAttribute value of the struct to False
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid non-public fields in ComVisible value types.

RuleInstance.Name: Static Method -> Avoid in ComVisible types
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid static members in ComVisible types
RuleInstance.Scope: Public
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Type that is specifically marked as visible to COM contains a public static method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
.NET components that are meant to be exposed to COM clients should not use features that COM-based clients cannot see.

COM does not support static methods. Therefore, such methods should not be exposed to COM clients.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Avoid static members in ComVisible types', CheckId CA1407
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change the System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisibleAttribute value of the method to False
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid static members in ComVisible types.

RuleInstance.Name: Class -> Com visible types should be creatable
RuleInstance.Title: Com visible types should be creatable
RuleInstance.Scope: Public
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Type marked as COM visible contains a public parameterized constructor but does not contain a public default (parameterless) constructor.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, the class must expose an implicit and explicit parameter-less constructor because COM clients can't access constructors with parameters. (The class might expose a public Initialize method that COM clients can call immediately after instantiation to ensure that the objectis in a valid state before using it.)

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Com visible types should be creatable', CheckId CA1409
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add a public default constructor
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Com visible types should be creatable.

RuleInstance.Name: PInvoke Method -> Should not be visible
RuleInstance.Title: PInvokes should not be visible
RuleInstance.Scope: Extern
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
Externally visible method in a public type has the System.Runtime.InteropServices.DllImportAttribute attribute.

- OR -

Externally visible method in a public type defined using the Declare keyword.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Methods defined using the Declare statement (or marked with the System.Runtime.InteropServices.DllImportAttribute attribute) use PInvoke (Platform Invocation Services) to call unmanaged functions that are implemented in a DLL. Therefore, if such method is externally visible, it maight be exploited and cause security vulnerability by allowing access to unmanaged API that could not be used otherwise.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'PInvokes should not be visible', CheckId CA1401
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change method modifier to Private.
  • Change method modifier to Internal
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • PInvokes should not be visible.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]

' This code will trigger the rule violation

Imports System
Imports System.Runtime.InteropServices

Namespace DiskManagementLibrary

  Public Class NativeDiskAccess

    ...

    ' Violates the rule
    Public Declare Function DeleteFile Lib "kernel32" _
      (ByVal lpFileName As String) As Boolean

  End Class

End Namespace 

' This is the correct implementation

Imports System
Imports System.Runtime.InteropServices

Namespace DiskManagementLibrary

  Public Class NativeDiskAccess

    ...

    Private Declare Function DeleteFile Lib "kernel32" _
      (ByVal lpFileName As String) As Boolean

  End Class

End Namespace

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

using System;
using System.Runtime.InteropServices;

namespace DiskManagementLibrary
{

  public class NativeDiskAccess
  {

    ...

    [DllImport("kernel32.dll", SetLastError = true)]
    [return: MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.Bool)]
    public static extern bool DeleteFile(string lpFileName); // Violates the rule

  }

}


// This is the correct implementation

using System;
using System.Runtime.InteropServices;

namespace DiskManagementLibrary
{

  public class NativeDiskAccess
  {

    ...

    [DllImport("kernel32.dll", SetLastError = true)]
    [return: MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.Bool)]
    private static extern bool DeleteFile(string lpFileName);

  }

}

RuleInstance.Name: Long Acronym -> Pascal Cased
RuleInstance.Title: Long Acronyms should be Pascal cased
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.Targets: Namespace, Class, Interface, Delegate, Struct, Enumeration, Module, Type, Method, Operator, Event, Property, Indexer, EnumerationItem, Parameter, Constant, Field, Member
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of an identifier contains an acronym of three or more uppercase letters (long acronym) or a two-letter acronym and the second letter is lowercase (short acronym).
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to naming guidelines short acronyms (two-letter acronyms) should contain all uppercase letters, and long acronyms (three and more letters acronyms) should be Pascal cased.

This rule is similar to the following FxCop rules:
  • 'Long acronyms should be pascal-cased', CheckId CA1705
  • 'Short acronyms should be uppercase', CheckId CA1706
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename code element and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties:
• Acronym - Type of acronym used. Possible values: Short, Long;
  • ExceptionList - A comma-separated list of the acronyms excluded from analysis.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Long Acronyms should be Pascal cased.
  • Short Acronyms should be Upper cased
