RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of an identifier contains an acronym of three or more uppercase letters (long acronym) or a two-letter acronym and the second letter is lowercase (short acronym).
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:

RuleInstance.Name: Only Collection Class -> "Collection" Suffix
RuleInstance.Title: Only Collection class name must have "Collection" suffix
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.Targets: Class, Interface, Delegate, Struct, Enumeration, Module, Type
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of the type or derived type has incorrect suffix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to the Microsoft naming guidelines for the .NET Framework types, the name of the type or derived type should not end with one of specific reserved suffixes. These suffixes can be used only in the name of the type that extends certain base type, implement certain interface or derived from such types.

The table below represents base types and interfaces with corresponding reserved suffixes:
SuffixName of base type or interface
AttributeSystem.Attribute
CollectionSystem.Collections.Generic.ICollection
System.Collections.ICollection
System.Collections.IEnumerable
System.Collections.Queue
System.Collections.Stack
System.Data.DataSet
System.Data.DataTable
DictionarySystem.Collections.Generic.IDictionary
System.Collections.IDictionary
EventArgsSystem.EventArgs
EventHandlerAn event-handler delegate.
ExceptionSystem.Exception
PermissionSystem.Security.IPermission
QueueSystem.Collections.Queue
StackSystem.Collections.Stack
StreamSystem.IO.Stream

The following suffixes are reserved as well: Delegate, Enum, Flags (for an enumeration) and Impl.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should not have incorrect suffix', CheckId CA1711
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename type and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties:
• MustImplement - Type should implement the specified type or interface;
  • SuffixToCheck - Certain Suffix to be checked.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Only Collection class name must have "Collection" suffix.
  • Only Dictionary class name must have "Dictionary" suffix.
  • Only Exception class name must have "Exception" suffix
  • Only Attribute class name must have "Attribute" suffix
  • Only Condition class name must have "Condition" suffix
  • Only Queue class name must have "Queue" suffix
  • Only Stack class name must have "Stack" suffix
  • Only Stream class name must have "Stream" suffix
  • Only Permission class name must have "Permission" suffix
  • Only EventArgs class name must have "EventArgs" suffix
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]

' The following example shows incorrectly named types

Public Class MySampleDictionary
	
	...
	
End Class


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Public Class MySample
	
	...
	
End Class

- Or -

Public Class MySampleDictionary
	Implements IDictionary
	
	...
	
End Class

[C#]

// The following example shows incorrectly named types

public class MySampleDictionary
{
	
	...
	
}


// This code will trigger the rule violation

public class MySample
{
	
	...
	
}

- Or -

public class MySampleDictionary: IDictionary
{
	
	...
	
}

RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of the type or derived type has incorrect suffix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to the Microsoft naming guidelines for the .NET Framework types, the name of the type or derived type should not end with one of specific reserved suffixes. These suffixes can be used only in the name of the type that extends certain base type, implement certain interface or derived from such types.

The table below represents base types and interfaces with corresponding reserved suffixes:
SuffixName of base type or interface
AttributeSystem.Attribute
CollectionSystem.Collections.Generic.ICollection
System.Collections.ICollection
System.Collections.IEnumerable
System.Collections.Queue
System.Collections.Stack
System.Data.DataSet
System.Data.DataTable
DictionarySystem.Collections.Generic.IDictionary
System.Collections.IDictionary
EventArgsSystem.EventArgs
EventHandlerAn event-handler delegate.
ExceptionSystem.Exception
PermissionSystem.Security.IPermission
QueueSystem.Collections.Queue
StackSystem.Collections.Stack
StreamSystem.IO.Stream

The following suffixes are reserved as well: Delegate, Enum, Flags (for an enumeration) and Impl.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should not have incorrect suffix', CheckId CA1711
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename type and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties:
• MustImplement - Type should implement the specified type or interface;
  • SuffixToCheck - Certain Suffix to be checked.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Only Collection class name must have "Collection" suffix.
  • Only Dictionary class name must have "Dictionary" suffix.
  • Only Exception class name must have "Exception" suffix
  • Only Attribute class name must have "Attribute" suffix
  • Only Condition class name must have "Condition" suffix
  • Only Queue class name must have "Queue" suffix
  • Only Stack class name must have "Stack" suffix
  • Only Stream class name must have "Stream" suffix
  • Only Permission class name must have "Permission" suffix
  • Only EventArgs class name must have "EventArgs" suffix
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]

' The following example shows incorrectly named types

Public Class MySampleDictionary
	
	...
	
End Class


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Public Class MySample
	
	...
	
End Class

- Or -

Public Class MySampleDictionary
	Implements IDictionary
	
	...
	
End Class

[C#]

// The following example shows incorrectly named types

public class MySampleDictionary
{
	
	...
	
}


// This code will trigger the rule violation

public class MySample
{
	
	...
	
}

- Or -

public class MySampleDictionary: IDictionary
{
	
	...
	
}

RuleInstance.Name: Parameter -> Avoid Language Specific Type Names
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid language specific type names in parameters
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: According to the Microsoft naming guidelines for the .NET Framework types, the name of the parameter should not contain a language-specific type name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Use names that reflect the meaning of the parameter and avoid prefixes and suffixes that indicate the type of a parameter.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Avoid language specific type names in parameters', CheckId CA1718
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename parameter and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid language specific type names in parameters.

RuleInstance.Name: Enumeration value -> Avoid Prefix With Type Name
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid prefix enumeration values with type name
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: An enumeration contains a member whose name begins with the type name of the enumeration.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Enumeration members names are not prefixed with the type name because type information is redundant.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not prefix enum values with type name', CheckId CA1712
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename enumeration member and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid prefix enumeration values with type name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]

' This code will trigger the rule violation
	
Public Enum ImageMode

    ImageModeBitmap = 0
    ImageModeGrayscale = 1
    ImageModeIndexed = 2
    ImageModeRgb = 3
    
End Enum


' This is the correct implementation
	
Public Enum ImageMode

    Bitmap = 0
    Grayscale = 1
    Indexed = 2
    Rgb = 3
    
End Enum

[C#]

// This code will trigger the rule violation
	
public enum ImageMode
{

    ImageModeBitmap = 0,
    ImageModeGrayscale = 1,
    ImageModeIndexed = 2,
    ImageModeRgb = 3
    
}


// This is the correct implementation
	
public enum ImageMode
{

    Bitmap = 0,
    Grayscale = 1,
    Indexed = 2,
    Rgb = 3
    
}

RuleInstance.Name: Enumeration value -> Avoid 'Reserved' Name
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid name enumeration values 'Reserved'
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of the member of enumeration includes the "Reserved" word.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Don't use the word "Reserved" in the name of an enumeration member. Defining such reserved values is a holdover from COM programming. A later version of a Microsoft .NET Framework class library can simply add new values as and when required, without breaking existing clients, provided that you don't change the numeric value of existing values.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not name enum values Reserved', CheckId CA1700
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The word "Reserved" should be removed from the name of the member of enumeration. Do not include "reserved for future use" values in an enum value.

The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename enumeration member and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties: • NameToAvoid - Name to be avoid in enum members.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid name enumeration values "Reserved".
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Enum SampleType

  Unknown = 0
  Known = 1
  SomeOtherReserved = 2

End Enum


' This is the correct implementation

Enum SampleType

  Unknown = 0
  Known = 1

End Enum

- Or -

Enum SampleType

  Unknown = 0
  Known = 1
  SomeOther = 2

End Enum

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

enum SampleType
{

  Unknown = 0,
  Known = 1,
  SomeOtherReserved = 2

}


// This is the correct implementation

enum SampleType
{

  Unknown = 0,
  Known = 1

}

- Or -

enum SampleType
{

  Unknown = 0,
  Known = 1,
  SomeOther = 2

}

RuleInstance.Name: Namespace/Type -> Pascal Cased
RuleInstance.Title: Namespace/Type identifiers should be cased correctly
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.Targets: Namespace, Class, Interface, Delegate, Struct, Enumeration, Module, Type
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of an identifier is not cased correctly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to the Microsoft naming guidelines for the .NET Framework types, the following capitalization rules should be used for the different types of identifiers:

Pascal case should be used for:
- Class
- Enum type
- Enum values
- Event
- Exception class
- Read-only Static field
- Interface
- Method
- Namespace
- Property
- Public instance field

Camel case should be used for:
- Parameter
- Protected instance field

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should be cased correctly', CheckId CA1709
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename code element and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties: • IdentifierCase - Name case notation to check. Possible values: Camel, Pascal, Upper
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Namespace/Type identifiers should be cased correctly.
  • Member identifiers should be cased correctly.
  • Field identifiers should be cased correctly.
  • Parameter identifiers should be cased correctly.
  • Local variable identifiers should be cased correctly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Public Class sampleClass
	Protected InstanceField As String = String.Empty
	
	...
	
End Class


' This is the correct implementation

Public Class SampleClass
	Protected instanceField As String = String.Empty
	
	...
	
End Class

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

public class sampleClass
{
	protected string InstanceField = String.Empty;
	
	...
	
}


' This is the correct implementation

public class SampleClass
{
	protected string instanceField = String.Empty;
	
	...
	
}

RuleInstance.Name: Member Parameters -> Differ By More Then Case
RuleInstance.Title: Member parameter names should differ by more than case
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The names of two types, members, parameters, or fully qualified namespaces are identical when converted to lower-case.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Identifiers for namespaces, types, members, and parameters cannot differ only by case because languages that target the common language runtime are not required to be case-sensitive. For example, Visual Basic is a widely used case-insensitive language.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should differ by more than case', CheckId CA1708
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename identifier and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Member parameter names should differ by more than case.
  • Type member names should differ by more than case.
  • Identifiers should differ by more than case.

RuleInstance.Name: Type Members -> Differ By More Than Case
RuleInstance.Title: Type member names should differ by more than case
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The names of two types, members, parameters, or fully qualified namespaces are identical when converted to lower-case.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Identifiers for namespaces, types, members, and parameters cannot differ only by case because languages that target the common language runtime are not required to be case-sensitive. For example, Visual Basic is a widely used case-insensitive language.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should differ by more than case', CheckId CA1708
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename identifier and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Member parameter names should differ by more than case.
  • Type member names should differ by more than case.
  • Identifiers should differ by more than case.

RuleInstance.Name: Namespace Types -> Differ By More Than Case

RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The names of two types, members, parameters, or fully qualified namespaces are identical when converted to lower-case.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Identifiers for namespaces, types, members, and parameters cannot differ only by case because languages that target the common language runtime are not required to be case-sensitive. For example, Visual Basic is a widely used case-insensitive language.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should differ by more than case', CheckId CA1708
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename identifier and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Member parameter names should differ by more than case.
  • Type member names should differ by more than case.
  • Identifiers should differ by more than case.

RuleInstance.Name: Namespace/Type -> Avoid Underscores
RuleInstance.Title: Namespace and type names should not contain underscores
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.Targets: Namespace, Class, Interface, Delegate, Struct, Enumeration, Module, Type
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of an identifier contains the specified character.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Remove the specified character from identifier's name and rename an identifier and its references.
  • Rename an identifier and its references to the specified name.
This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should not contain underscores', CheckId CA1707
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename code element and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties: • ForbiddenChar - Should not contain a character.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Namespace and type names should not contain underscores.
  • Public member names should not contain underscores.
  • Parameter names should not contain underscores.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

  Imports System
  Imports System.IO
  Imports System.Text
  
  Public Class _SampleFileReader
  
    ...
  
  End Class


' This is the correct implementation

  Imports System
  Imports System.IO
  Imports System.Text
  
  Public Class SampleFileReader
  
    ...

  End Class

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

  using System;
  using System.IO;
  using System.Text;
  
  public class _SampleFileReader
  {
  
    ...
  
  }


// This is the correct implementation

  using System;
  using System.IO;
  using System.Text;
  
  public class SampleFileReader
  {
  
    ...

  }

RuleInstance.Name: Namespace/Type -> Avoid Match Keywords
RuleInstance.Title: Namespace or Type names should not match keywords
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.Targets: Namespace, Class, Interface, Delegate, Struct, Enumeration, Module, Type
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A namespace name or a type name matches a reserved keyword in a case-insensitive comparison.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Identifiers for namespaces and types should not match keywords defined by languages that target the common language runtime. Depending on the language in use and the keyword, compiler errors and ambiguities can make the library difficult to use. This rule does not check all keywords in all .NET languages

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should not match keywords', CheckId CA1716
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename an identifier and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Namespace or Type names should not match keywords.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

  Public Class Operator
  
    ...
  
  End Class


' This is the correct implementation

  Public Class MyOperator
  
    ...

  End Class

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

  public class Delegate
  {
  
    ...
  
  }


// This is the correct implementation

  public class MyDelegate
  {
  
    ...

  }
	
	</

RuleInstance.Name: Parameter -> Match Base Declaration
RuleInstance.Title: Parameter names should match base declaration
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of the parameter in the derived method does not match the name of the parameter in the base declaration of that method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The name of the parameter in the derived (overrided) method should match the name of the parameter in the base declaration of that method. Observance of that rule alows to avoid possible confusion and increases usability of derived methods.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Parameter names should match base declaration', CheckId CA1725
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename parameter and its references to the base declaration parameter name.
  • Rename parameter and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Parameter names should match base declaration.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]

' The base declaration of the System.ComponentModel.IBindingList.AddIndex method is:

Sub AddIndex (property As PropertyDescriptor)


' This code will trigger the rule violation

' The following Persons type implements System.ComponentModel.IBindingList interface.


Imports System.ComponentModel

Public Class Persons
    Implements IBindingList

	...

    Public Sub AddIndex(propertyValue As PropertyDescriptor) Implements IBindingList.AddIndex
    
        ' method code
        
    End Sub

	...

End Class


' This is the correct implementation

Imports System.ComponentModel

Public Class Persons
    Implements IBindingList

	...

    Public Sub AddIndex([property] As PropertyDescriptor) Implements IBindingList.AddIndex
    
        ' method code
        
    End Sub

	...

End Class

[C#]

// The base declaration of the System.ComponentModel.IBindingList.AddIndex method is:

void AddIndex(PropertyDescriptor property)


// This code will trigger the rule violation

// The following Persons type implements System.ComponentModel.IBindingList interface.


using System.ComponentModel;

public class Persons: IBindingList
{

	...

    public void IBindingList.AddIndex(PropertyDescriptor propertyValue)
    {
    
        // method code
        
    }

	...

}


// This is the correct implementation

using System.ComponentModel;

public class Persons: IBindingList
{

	...


    public void IBindingList.AddIndex(PropertyDescriptor property)
    {
    
        // method code
        
    }

	...

}

RuleInstance.Name: Parameter -> Avoid Match Member Name
RuleInstance.Title: Parameter names should not match member names
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of one of parameters matches the name of the method in the case-insensetive comparison.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to the Microsoft naming guidelines for the .NET Framework types, names of the parameters should be descriptive and reflect the meaning of the parameter. The same naming for the parameter and for the method is unintuitive.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Parameter names should not match member names', CheckId CA1719
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename parameter and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Parameter names should not match member names.

RuleInstance.Name: Property -> Avoid Match Get Methods
RuleInstance.Title: Property names should not match get methods
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of a public or protected member starts with "Get" and otherwise matches the name of a public or protected property.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Get methods and properties should have names that clearly distinguish their function.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Property names should not match get methods', CheckId CA1721
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename property and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Property names should not match get methods.

RuleInstance.Name: Type -> Avoid Match Namespaces
RuleInstance.Title: Type names should not match namespaces
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.Targets: Class, Interface, Delegate, Struct, Enumeration, Module, Type
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The class name duplicates commonly used .NET Framework namespace.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
Rename class and choose new name that does not duplicate commonly used .NET Framework namespaces.

The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename type and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Type names should not match namespaces.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Namespace MyNamespace

	Public Class Forms
		
		...
		
	End Class

End Namespace


' This is the correct implementation

Namespace MyNamespace

	Public Class MyForms
		
		...
		
	End Class

End Namespace

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

namespace MyNamespace
{

	public class Forms
	{
		
		...
		
	}

}


// This is the correct implementation

namespace MyNamespace
{

	public class MyForms
	{
		
		...
		
	}

}
	</

RuleInstance.Name: Dictionary Class -> "Dictionary" Suffix
RuleInstance.Title: Dictionary class name must have "Dictionary" suffix
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of the type or derived type does not have correct suffix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to the Microsoft naming guidelines for the .NET Framework types, the name of the type that extends certain base type, implement certain interface or derived from such types should end with one of specific reserved suffixes. These suffixes cannot be used in the name of other types.

The table below represents base types and interfaces with corresponding reserved suffixes that should be used in the names of derived types:
Name of base type or interface Suffix
System.Attribute Attribute
System.EventArgs EventArgs
System.Exception Exception
System.Collections.Generic.ICollection Collection
System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary Dictionary
System.Collections.ICollection Collection
System.Collections.IDictionary Dictionary
System.Collections.IEnumerable Collection
System.Collections.Queue Collection or Queue
System.Collections.Stack Collection or Stack
System.Data.DataSet Collection or DataSet
System.Data.DataTable Collection or DataTable
System.IO.Stream Stream
System.Security.IPermission Permission
System.Security.Policy.IMembershipCondition Condition
An event-handler delegate. EventHandler

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should have correct suffix', CheckId CA1710
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
Modify the name of the type so that it include correct suffix.

The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename type and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties:
• MustImplement - Type should implement the specified type or interface;
  • SuffixToCheck - Certain Suffix to be checked.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Dictionary class name must have "Dictionary" suffix.
  • Generic Dictionary class name must have "Dictionary" suffix.
  • Exception class name must have "Exception" suffix.
  • Attribute class name must have "Attribute" suffix.
  • Condition class name must have "Condition" suffix.
  • Queue class name must have "Queue" suffix.
  • Stack class name must have "Stack" suffix.
  • Stream class name must have "Stream" suffix.
  • Permission class name must have "Permission" suffix.
  • EventArgs class name must have "EventArgs" suffix.
  • DataSet class name must have "DataSet" suffix.
  • Derived types should have correct suffix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Public Class MySample
	Implements IDictionary
	
	...
	
End Class


' This is the correct implementation

Public Class MySampleDictionary
	Implements IDictionary
	
	...
	
End Class

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

public class MySample: IDictionary
{
	
	...
	
}


// This is the correct implementation

public class MySampleDictionary: IDictionary
{
	
	...
	
}

Modify the name of the type so that it include correct suffix.

The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename type and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties:
• MustImplement - Type should implement the specified type or interface;
  • SuffixToCheck - Certain Suffix to be checked.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Dictionary class name must have "Dictionary" suffix.
  • Generic Dictionary class name must have "Dictionary" suffix.
  • Exception class name must have "Exception" suffix.
  • Attribute class name must have "Attribute" suffix.
  • Condition class name must have "Condition" suffix.
  • Queue class name must have "Queue" suffix.
  • Stack class name must have "Stack" suffix.
  • Stream class name must have "Stream" suffix.
  • Permission class name must have "Permission" suffix.
  • EventArgs class name must have "EventArgs" suffix.
  • DataSet class name must have "DataSet" suffix.
  • Derived types should have correct suffix.

}

RuleInstance.Name: Queue Class -> "Queue" Suffix
RuleInstance.Title: Queue class name must have "Queue" suffix

RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of the type or derived type does not have correct suffix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to the Microsoft naming guidelines for the .NET Framework types, the name of the type that extends certain base type, implement certain interface or derived from such types should end with one of specific reserved suffixes. These suffixes cannot be used in the name of other types.

The table below represents base types and interfaces with corresponding reserved suffixes that should be used in the names of derived types:
Name of base type or interface Suffix
System.Attribute Attribute
System.EventArgs EventArgs
System.Exception Exception
System.Collections.Generic.ICollection Collection
System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary Dictionary
System.Collections.ICollection Collection
System.Collections.IDictionary Dictionary
System.Collections.IEnumerable Collection
System.Collections.Queue Collection or Queue
System.Collections.Stack Collection or Stack
System.Data.DataSet Collection or DataSet
System.Data.DataTable Collection or DataTable
System.IO.Stream Stream
System.Security.IPermission Permission
System.Security.Policy.IMembershipCondition Condition
An event-handler delegate. EventHandler

RuleInstance.Name: Collection Class -> "Collection" Suffix
RuleInstance.Title: Collection class name must have "Collection" suffix
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The type implements System.Collections.ICollection or System.Collections.IEnumerable and its name does not have a Collection suffix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Use the Collection suffix for the collection types that inherit from the System.Collections.CollectionBase or System.Collections.ReadOnlyCollectionBase, for types that implement System.Collections.IList interface, and, more generally, for types that behave like System.Collections.ArrayList and whose members can be indexed by their position.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should have correct suffix', CheckId CA1710
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename type and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Collection class name must have "Collection" suffix.

RuleInstance.Name: Interface -> "I" Prefix
RuleInstance.Title: Use "I" prefix for Interface types
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Some programming elements have name that begins with incorrect prefix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to the Microsoft naming guidelines for the .NET Framework types, only certain programming elements should have names that begin with a specific prefix.

Class Naming: Do not use a type prefix, such as C for class, on a class name.

For example: CPersonInfo and TEmployee are incorrect type names; PersonInfo and Employee are correct type names.

Interface Naming: Prefix interface names with the letter I, to indicate that the type is an interface.

For example: Comparable or Disposable are incorrect interface names; IComparable or IDisposable are correct interface names.

Static Field Naming: Do not use a Hungarian notation prefix on static field names.

Parameter Naming: Do not prefix parameter names with Hungarian type notation.

Event Naming: Do not use a prefix on the event declaration on the type.

This rule is similar to the following FxCop rules:
  • 'Identifiers should have correct prefix', CheckId CA1715
  • 'Identifiers should not have incorrect prefix', CheckId CA1722
  • 'Events should not have before or after prefix', CheckId CA1713
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename code element and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties:
• PrefixUsage - Should prefix be used or avoided. Possible values: None, Avoid, Use;
  • PrefixToCheck - Certain prefix to be checked;
  • NextCharCapitalizationStyle - Capitalization style of the next after prefix char. Possible values: None, Lower, Upper.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Use "I" prefix for Interface types.
  • Avoid to use "C" prefix for type names.
  • Only Interface types should have "I" prefix.
  • Event name must not have "Before" prefix.
  • Event name must not have "After" prefix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

  Imports System
  Imports System.IO
  Imports System.Text
  
  Public Class CSampleFileReader
  
    ...
  
  End Class


' This is the correct implementation

  Imports System
  Imports System.IO
  Imports System.Text
  
  Public Class SampleFileReader
  
    ...
  
  End Class

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

  using System;
  using System.IO;
  using System.Text;
  
  public class CSampleFileReader
  {
  
    ...
  
  }


// This is the correct implementation

  using System;
  using System.IO;
  using System.Text;
  
  public class SampleFileReader
  {
  
    ...
  
  }

RuleInstance.Name: Only Interface -> "I" prefix
RuleInstance.Title: Only Interface types should have "I" prefix
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Some programming elements have name that begins with incorrect prefix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to the Microsoft naming guidelines for the .NET Framework types, only certain programming elements should have names that begin with a specific prefix.

Class Naming: Do not use a type prefix, such as C for class, on a class name.

For example: CPersonInfo and TEmployee are incorrect type names; PersonInfo and Employee are correct type names.

Interface Naming: Prefix interface names with the letter I, to indicate that the type is an interface.

For example: Comparable or Disposable are incorrect interface names; IComparable or IDisposable are correct interface names.

Static Field Naming: Do not use a Hungarian notation prefix on static field names.

Parameter Naming: Do not prefix parameter names with Hungarian type notation.

Event Naming: Do not use a prefix on the event declaration on the type.

This rule is similar to the following FxCop rules:
  • 'Identifiers should have correct prefix', CheckId CA1715
  • 'Identifiers should not have incorrect prefix', CheckId CA1722
  • 'Events should not have before or after prefix', CheckId CA1713
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename code element and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties:
• PrefixUsage - Should prefix be used or avoided. Possible values: None, Avoid, Use;
  • PrefixToCheck - Certain prefix to be checked;
  • NextCharCapitalizationStyle - Capitalization style of the next after prefix char. Possible values: None, Lower, Upper.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Use "I" prefix for Interface types.
  • Avoid to use "C" prefix for type names.
  • Only Interface types should have "I" prefix.
  • Event name must not have "Before" prefix.
  • Event name must not have "After" prefix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

  Imports System
  Imports System.IO
  Imports System.Text
  
  Public Class CSampleFileReader
  
    ...
  
  End Class


' This is the correct implementation

  Imports System
  Imports System.IO
  Imports System.Text
  
  Public Class SampleFileReader
  
    ...
  
  End Class

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

  using System;
  using System.IO;
  using System.Text;
  
  public class CSampleFileReader
  {
  
    ...
  
  }


// This is the correct implementation

  using System;
  using System.IO;
  using System.Text;
  
  public class SampleFileReader
  {
  
    ...
  
  }

RuleInstance.Name: Type -> Avoid "Impl" Suffix
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid to use "Impl" suffix for type names
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.Targets: Class, Interface, Delegate, Struct, Enumeration, Module, Type
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The name of some type ends with incorrect suffix.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to the Microsoft naming guidelines for the .NET Framework types, only the names of types that extend certain base types or that implement certain interfaces, or types derived from these types, should end with specific reserved suffixes.

Event Naming:
- Use an EventHandler suffix on event handler names.
- Name an event argument class with the EventArgs suffix.
- Do not use a suffix on the event declaration on the type.

Attribute Naming:
- You should always add the suffix Attribute to custom attribute classes.

Enumeration Type Naming:
- Do not use an Enum suffix on Enum type names.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Identifiers should not have incorrect suffix', CheckId CA1711
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename code element and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties:
• SuffixUsage - Should suffix be used or avoided. Possible values: None, Avoid, Use;
  • SuffixToCheck - Certain Suffix to be checked.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid to use "Impl" suffix for type names.
  • Avoid to use "Enum" suffix for non enumeration types.
  • Avoid to use "Flags" suffix for non enumeration types.
  • Avoid to use "Delegate" suffix for non delegate types.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]

' The following example shows incorrectly named types

Public Class DictionaryImpl
	Implements IDictionary
	
	...
	
End Class


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Public Class MyDictionary
	Implements IDictionary
	
	...
	
End Class

[C#]

// The following example shows incorrectly named types

public class DictionaryImpl: IDictionary
{
	
	...
	
}


// This code will trigger the rule violation

public class MyDictionary: IDictionary
{
	
	...
	
}

RuleInstance.Name: Flags Enumeration -> Plural Name
RuleInstance.Title: Enums should have plural names depending on Flag attribute
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
An externally visible enumeration has the System.FlagsAttribute attribute specified, but does not ends in a plural word.

Or

An externally visible enumeration ends in a plural word, but does not have the System.FlagsAttribute attribute specified.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The System.FlagsAttribute indicates that an enumeration can be treated as a bit field; that is, a set of flags. Bit fields are generally used for lists of elements that might occur in combination, whereas enumeration constants are generally used for lists of mutually exclusive elements.

Therefore, if only one value of an enumeration can be specified at a time, then the name of the enumeration should be a singular word and the enum should not be marked with the System.FlagsAttribute attribute.

If more than one value of the enumeration can be specified simultaneously, then the name of the enumeration should be a plural word and the enum should be marked with the System.FlagsAttribute attribute.

This rule is similar to the following FxCop rules:
  • 'Flags enums should have plural names', CheckId CA1714
  • 'Only FlagsAttribute enums should have plural names', CheckId CA1717
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
Rename externally visible enumeration according to the System.FlagsAttribute attribute.

The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Rename enumeration and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleConfigurableProperties: • CheckFlagEnum - Whether check Flag or Non-Flag enumeration.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Enums should have plural names depending on Flag attribute.
  • Enums should have plural names depending on Flag attribute.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

<FlagsAttribute( )> _
Enum Color
  Red = 1
  Green = 2
  Blue = 4
End Enum


' This is the correct implementation

<FlagsAttribute( )> _
Enum Colors
  Red = 1
  Green = 2
  Blue = 4
End Enum

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

[FlagsAttribute( )]
enum Color
{
  Red = 1,
  Green = 2,
  Blue = 4
}


// This is the correct implementation

[FlagsAttribute( )]
enum Colors
{
  Red = 1,
  Green = 2,
  Blue = 4
}
	</

RuleInstance.Name: Class -> Avoid unsealed attributes
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid unsealed attributes
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A type inherits from System.Attribute, is not abstract, and is not sealed (NotInheritable in Visual Basic).
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, classes for custom attributes should be sealed (NotInheritable in Visual Basic), unless rare cases when you need to inherit from the custom attribute.

The .NET Framework methods for retrieving custom attributes, such as System.Attribute.GetCustomAttribute, search the attribute inheritance hierarchy, which can be a time consuming operation. Sealing the attribute class can improve performance, eliminating the search through the inheritance hierarchy.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Avoid unsealed attributes', CheckId CA1813
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change type modifier to sealed.
  • Change type modifier to abstract.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid unsealed attributes.

RuleInstance.Name: Type -> Remove if unused
RuleInstance.Title: Remove unused internal classes
RuleInstance.Scope: Internal, Private
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The type is not externally visible and its instance is not created by code within the assembly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Assembly-level (private or internal) types, that does not instantiated in the assembly, increase the size of an assembly and degrade performance.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Avoid uninstantiated internal classes', CheckId CA1812
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Comment out the type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:

  • Remove unused internal classes.

RuleInstance.Scope: Public

RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Public types, that does not instantiated in the assembly, increase the size of an assembly and degrade performance.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Avoid uninstantiated internal classes', CheckId CA1812

The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Comment out the type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
