RuleInstance.Name: Field -> Do not initialize unnecessarily
RuleInstance.Title: Do not initialize unnecessarily
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The field is initialized with its default value.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The fields, that is initialized with its default value in the constructor, increase the size of an assembly and degrade performance. Such initialization is redundant, because the CLR (Common Language Runtime) initializes all fields with their default values before running the constructor.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not initialize unnecessarily', CheckId CA1805
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Remove the field initialization.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not initialize unnecessarily.

RuleInstance.Name: Check for an empty string using Equals -> Do not use
RuleInstance.Title: Do not check for empty strings using Equals
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A string should not be compared to an empty string using System.Object.Equals.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Length property of a string should be compared with zero, rather than comparing a string with "" or String.Empty.
This technique delivers better performance.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Test for empty strings using string length', CheckId CA1820
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change the comparison to use the IsNullOrEmpty(System.String) method and test for the null string.
  • Change the comparison to use the Length property and test for the null string.
  • Change the comparison to use the IsNullOrEmpty(System.String) method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not check for empty strings using Equals.

RuleInstance.Name: Field -> Use constants where appropriate
RuleInstance.Title: Use constants where appropriate
RuleInstance.Scope: Internal, Private, Static, Readonly
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The field is declared as static and readonly (Shared and ReadOnly in Visual Basic), but is initialized with a constant value.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The value of a static readonly (Shared ReadOnly in Visual Basic) field is computed at runtime when the static constructor is called. If a static constructor is not declared explicitly, the compiler emits it to initialize the field.

The value of the const (Const in Visual Basic) field is computed in the compile time and stored in the metadata. That increases runtime performance. Therefore, const (Const in Visual Basic) field should be used instead of static readonly (Shared ReadOnly in Visual Basic) field if the value of the field is computable in the compile time.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Use literals where appropriate', CheckId CA1802
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Replace static readonly (Shared ReadOnly in Visual Basic) modifiers with the const (Const in Visual Basic) modifier.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Use constants where appropriate.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Imports System

Public Class MyClass
			
  Shared ReadOnly IntField As Integer = 2
  Shared ReadOnly DoubleField As Double = IntField * 3.14
  Shared ReadOnly StringField As String = "string"

  ...

End Class


' This is the correct implementation

Imports System

Public Class MyClass
			
  Const IntField As Integer = 2
  Const DoubleField As Double = IntField * 3.14
  Const StringField As String = "string"

  ...

End Class

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

using System;

public class MyClass
{
    
  static readonly int IntField = 2;
  static readonly double DoubleField = IntField * 3.14;
  static readonly string StringField = "string";

  ...

}


// This is the correct implementation

using System;

public class MyClass
{
    
  const int IntField = 2;
  const double DoubleField = IntField * 3.14;
  const string StringField = "string";

  ...

}

RuleInstance.Name: Dispose -> Type -> Dispose methods should call SuppressFinalize
RuleInstance.Title: Dispose methods should call SuppressFinalize
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A type implements System.IDisposable.Dispose, but does not prevent the Finalize method from running by calling the GC.SuppressFinalize method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
IDisposable.Dispose method performs application-defined tasks associated with freeing, releasing, or resetting unmanaged resources. Because the Dispose method must be called explicitly, objects that implement IDisposable must also implement a finalizer to handle freeing resources when Dispose is not called. By default, the garbage collector will automatically call an object's finalizer prior to reclaiming its memory. However, once the Dispose method has been called, it is typically unnecessary for the garbage collector to call the disposed object's finalizer. To prevent automatic finalization, Dispose implementations can call the GC.SuppressFinalize method.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Dispose methods should call SuppressFinalize', CheckId CA1816
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Find the Dispose method and insert call to GC.SuppressFinalize at the end of the method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Dispose methods should call SuppressFinalize.

RuleInstance.Name: Value Type -> Override equals and operator equals
RuleInstance.Title: Override equals and operator equals on value types
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
Equality operator == does not implemented by the public value type.

Or

System.Object.Equals does not overrided by the public value type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The inherited implementation of Equals for value types compares the contents of all fields using the Reflection library, which is computationally expensive.

The following guidelines should be considered for implementing a value type:
  • Consider overriding Equals to gain increased performance over that provided by the default implementation of Equals on ValueType.
  • If you override Equals and the language supports operator overloading, you must overload the equality operator for your value type.
This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Override equals and operator equals on value types', CheckId CA1815
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Override System.Object.Equals method.
  • Implement the equality operator.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Override equals and operator equals on value types.

RuleInstance.Name: Property -> Should not return arrays
RuleInstance.Title: Properties should not return arrays
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A public or protected property in a public type returns an array.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The property must return a copy of the array, to keep the array tamper-proof, because of arrays returned by properties are not write-protected. Calling of such property affects performance negatively. According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, a method should be used when returning array.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Properties should not return arrays', CheckId CA1819
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Convert property to getter and/or setter method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Properties should not return arrays.

RuleInstance.Name: Finalize -> Method -> Remove if empty
RuleInstance.Title: Remove empty finalizers
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A type implements a finalizer that is empty or calls only the base type finalizer.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The protected Finalize method should only be implemented if the type must release one ore more unmanaged resources that it has directly allocated. Unnecessary Finalize method results in overhead at instantiation and suboptimal usage of memory.
The entire finalizer should be enclosed in #if DEBUG / #endif directives, if it is required for debugging.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Remove empty finalizers', CheckId CA1821
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Comment out the empty finalizer.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Remove empty finalizers.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Remove unused locals
RuleInstance.Title: Remove unused locals
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A method declares a local variable, but does not use the variable except possibly as the recipient of an assignment statement.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Unused local variables and unnecessary assignments increase the size of an assembly and degrade performance.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Remove unused locals', CheckId CA1804
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Comment out the declaration of the local variable.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Remove unused locals.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Remove if unused
RuleInstance.Title: Remove unused private methods
RuleInstance.Scope: Private
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A method does not have callers in the assembly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Assembly-level (private or internal) methods, that does not have callers in the assembly, and is not invoked by a delegate or by the CLR, increase the size of an assembly and degrade performance.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Avoid uncalled private code', CheckId CA1811
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Comment out the uncalled method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Remove unused private methods.

RuleInstance.Name: Class -> Should only extend aptca base types
RuleInstance.Title: Aptca types should only extend aptca base types
RuleInstance.Scope: Public
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Type in the assembly derives from the type declared in another assembly that does not have System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, types in assemblies marked with the System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute shouldn't derive from types defined in assemblies that aren't marked with the System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute. (By default, public and protected types in strong-named assemblies are protected with an InheritanceDemand, but the System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute disables this protection.)

System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute can be applied only to strong-named assemblies that are meant to be called from partially trusted assemblies. (By default, strong-named assemblies can be called only by fully trusted assemblies.)

The security issue occurs when a type in an assembly marked with the System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute inherits from a type in another assembly that isn't marked with this attribute and that is supposed to contain private data. In that case, untrusted caller gain access to information that should be available to fully trusted types only.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Aptca types should only extend aptca base types', CheckId CA2117
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute to the assembly
  • Remove System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute from the assembly
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Aptca types should only extend aptca base types.

RuleInstance.Name: Assembly -> Should declare minimum security
RuleInstance.Title: Assemblies should declare minimum security
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Assembly does not have attributes specifying its minimum, optional, or refused security permissions.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Assemblies should be marked with permission attributes specifying suitable RequestMinimum, RequestOptional, and RequestRefuse actions.

This rule ensures that the assembly has only the permissions that it strictly needs for its chores. By reducing the prmission set assigned to the assembly, you make it harder for malicious code to exploit your assembly to access protected resources.

The RequestMinimum action specifies the permissions that are necessary for the assembly to work correctly; if the .NET runtime can't grant these permissions, the assembly won't be loaded and a System.Security.Policy.PolicyException is thrown. The RequestOptional action specifies the permissions that the assembly would like to use but that aren't crucial for its operations; if one of these permissions isn't granted, the assembly loads all the same, but its user interfaceshould disable or hide all commands that would perform a prohibited action. The RequestRefuse action specifies permissionsthat the .NET runtime should never grant to the assembly.

The permission set granted to the assembly consists of all the permissions marked with the RequestMinimum action, plus all the permissions marked with the RequestOptional action, minus all the permissions marked with the RequestRefuse action. In all cases, however, an assembly won't be given permissions that aren't granted by the policy level and the code group the assembly belongs to.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Assemblies should declare minimum security', CheckId CA2209
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add suitable attribute to the assembly.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Assemblies should declare minimum security.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following example shows the attributes that can be applied to an assembly that requires permission to create user interface elements and access files by means of common file dialogs, that wants to be granted permission to use performance counters (but that can run without them), and that explicitly refuses to receive the permission to call unmanaged code:

[Visual Basic]


Imports System
Imports System.Security
Imports System.Security.Permissions

<Assembly: UIPermission(SecurityAction.RequestMinimum, Unrestricted:=True)>
<Assembly: FileDialogPermission(SecurityAction.RequestMinimum, Unrestricted:=True)>
<Assembly: PerformanceCounterPermission(SecurityAction.RequestOptional, Unrestricted:=True)>
<Assembly: SecurityPermission(SecurityAction.RequestRefuse, UnmanagedCode:=True)>

Namespace UserLibrary

	...

End Namespace

[C#]


using System;
using System.Security;
using System.Security.Permissions;

[assembly:UIPermission(SecurityAction.RequestMinimum, Unrestricted=true)]
[assembly:FileDialogPermission(SecurityAction.RequestMinimum, Unrestricted=true)]
[assembly:PerformanceCounterPermission(SecurityAction.RequestOptional, Unrestricted=true)]
[assembly:SecurityPermission(SecurityAction.RequestRefuse, UnmanagedCode=true)]

namespace UserLibrary
{

	...

}

RuleInstance.Name: Field -> Array fields should not be read only
RuleInstance.Title: Array fields should not be read only
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: An externally visible field that holds an array is declared read-only.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, a field should be marked with the ReadOnly (Visual Basic) or readonly (C#) keyword if the value of the field must not change after instantiation. If a read-only field contains an array, the reference to the array cannot be changed. However, the elements of such array can be changed. Therefore, an externally visible read-only field that holds an array maight be exploited and cause security vulnerability.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Array fields should not be read only', CheckId CA2105
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change field modifier and create a method that returns a clone of an array.
  • Manually replace the array with a strongly typed collection that cannot be changed.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Array fields should not be read only.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Aptca methods should only call aptca methods
RuleInstance.Title: Aptca methods should only call aptca methods
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Method in an assembly with the System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute calls method in assembly that does not have the attribute.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, methods in assemblies marked with the System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute should call methods in another assembly only if the other assembly is also marked with the System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute. This guideline ensures that untrusted assemblies cannot use the assembly marked with System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute to call into an assembly that isn't supposed to be available to untruted callers.

Methods in assemblies marked with the System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute should always demand one or more permissions from callers; exceptions to this rule are sometimes necessary but you should carefully review your code to ensure that untrusted assemblies cannot use your public methods to perform dangerous actions.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Aptca methods should only call aptca methods', CheckId CA2116
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute to the assembly
  • Remove System.Security.AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute from the assembly
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Aptca methods should only call aptca methods.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Wrap vulnerable finally clauses in outer try
RuleInstance.Title: Wrap vulnerable finally clauses in outer try
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: An externally visible method contains a try-finally block. The finally block appears to reset security state and is not enclosed in a finally block.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, always should be added a Catch (catch in C#) clause that traps all exceptions if the code in the Try (try in C#) block modifies any property of the current thread in a way that might be exploited by malicious code, for example, by impersonating a user with higher privileges.

A malicious exception filters presented in the call stack might execute before the Finally (finally in C#) block. An exception filter is a When clause implemented in Visual Basic.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Wrap vulnerable finally clauses in outer try', CheckId CA2124
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Wrap the finally clause in an outer try block with an associated catch that simply rethrows.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Wrap vulnerable finally clauses in outer try.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Security should be a superset of type
RuleInstance.Title: Method security should be a superset of type
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Type has declarative security and its method has declarative security for the same security action, and the security action is not LinkDemand or InheritanceDemand, and the permissions checked by the type are not a subset of the permissions checked by the method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
If the same declarative security action is applied to both a type and one of its methods, the permission checked at the method level should be more restrictive than the permission checked at the type level. (This gudeline doesn't apply to LinkDemand actions.)

If you mark both a type and one of its methods for the same security action but for a different range of permissions, the two permissions are not combined together. Instead, the type-level permission is ignored and only the method-level permission is applied.

If this guideline is ignored, malicious code might bypass the more restrictive type-level permissions by obtaining an istance of the type by some other means - for example, using a factory method exposed by a trusted assembly - and then invoke the method without any security exception.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Method security should be a superset of type', CheckId CA2114
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add required attribute(s) to the method.
  • Remove required attribute(s) from the type.
  • Remove required attribute(s) from the method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Method security should be a superset of type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

<FileIOPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, Unresticted:=True)> _
Public Class FileProcessing
  
  <FileIOPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, Read:="C:\Text")> _
  Public Function GetFile(ByVal fileName As String) As String
  
    ...
    
  End Function
  
  ...
  
End Class


' This is the correct implementation

<FileIOPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, Unresticted:=True)> _
Public Class FileProcessing
  
  Public Function GetFile(ByVal fileName As String) As String
  
    ...
    
  End Function
  
  ...
  
End Class

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

[FileIOPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, Unresticted = true)]
public class FileProcessing
{
  
  [FileIOPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, Read = "C:\Text")]
  public string GetFile(string fileName)
  {
  
    ...
    
  }
  
  ...
  
}


// This is the correct implementation

[FileIOPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, Unresticted = true)]
public class FileProcessing
{
  
  public string GetFile(string fileName)
  {
  
    ...
    
  }
  
  ...
  
}

RuleInstance.Name: Struct -> Review declarative security
RuleInstance.Title: Review declarative security on value types
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: An externally visible structure is secured by System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.Demand or System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.LinkDemand.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, a value type or its default constructor should not be protected with an imperative System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.Demand or System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.LinkDemand security action.

The .NET Framework allocates and initializes value types by means of their default (parameterless) constructor, and then executes any constructor with parameters explicitly invoked by the caller. If such a constructor is protected with a System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.Demand or System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.LinkDemand security action and the caller doesn't pass the security check, the .NET Framework throws an exception, but the instance of the value type still exists (as initialized by the default constructor) and its members can be used freely.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Review declarative security on value types', CheckId CA2108
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Remove attribute(s) from the structure.
  • Remove attribute(s) from the constructor.
  • Remove demand or link demand from the constructor manually.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Review declarative security on value types.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Review deny and permit only usage
RuleInstance.Title: Review deny and permit only usage
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A method contains a security check that specifies the System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.PermitOnly or System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.Deny security action.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.PermitOnly action defines a white list containing only the permissions that should be granted, whereas the System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.Deny action defines a black list containing all the permissions that should not be granted. According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, white lists are preferable to black lists, therefore System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.PermitOnly action is favorable over System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.Deny action. However, it is quite impactical to deny all the permissions that considered potentially dangerous and it is difficult to anticipate all the permissions that might be required.

Unreasoned using of System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.Deny and System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.PermitOnly security actions might alter the default behavior of the stack walk. Therefore, code that uses these security actions should be carefully evaluated by specialists in .NET Framework security.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Review deny and permit only usage', CheckId CA2107
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Remove attribute(s) from the method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Review declarative security on value types.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Review visible event handlers
RuleInstance.Title: Review visible event handlers
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
An externally visible event-handling method was detected.

- OR -

An externally visible method was detected that is decorated with a security demand and exposing an EventArgs parameter.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, private scope should be used for all event handlers.

The Demand security action checks whether an untrusted caller is in the call stack but cannot check whether the handler was added to the event source by untrusted code; also, the permission might be asserted at the time the event is raised. Therefore, malicious clients might attach your event handler to an event source so that your handler unknowingly executes dangerous code on behalf of the untrusted client.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Review visible event handlers', CheckId CA2109
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change method modifier to Private (private in C#).
  • Change method modifier to Friend (internal in C#).
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Review visible event handlers.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

Imports System

Public Class EventHandler
	
  ' Violation: event-handling method is public
  Public Sub HandleSomeEvent(sender As Object, e As EventArgs)
  
  ...
  
  End Sub

  ...

End Class


' This is the correct implementation

Imports System

Public Class EventHandler
	
  ' Correct implementation
  Private Sub HandleSomeEvent(sender As Object, e As EventArgs)
  
  ...
  
  End Sub

  ...

End Class

[C#]


// This code will trigger the rule violation

using System;

public class EventHandler
{
	
  // Violation: event-handling method is public
  public void HandleSomeEvent(object sender, EventArgs e)
  {
  
  ...
  
  }

  ...

}


' This is the correct implementation

using System;

public class EventHandler
{
	
  private void HandleSomeEvent(object sender, EventArgs e)
  {
  
  ...
  
  }

  ...

}

RuleInstance.Name: Type -> Secure serialization constructors
RuleInstance.Title: Secure serialization constructors
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Type implements the System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable interface, has a serialization constructor with the System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo, System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext parameter signature. This constructor is not secured by a security check, but one or more of the regular constructors in the type is secured.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, the constructor implied by the System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable interface should be protected with the same security actions used to protect other constructors.

Ignoring this guideline might result in a security risk because a malicious caller might serialize an instance obtained through a factory method exposed by a trusted assembly and then create a copy of it at a later time.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Secure serialization constructors', CheckId CA2120
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add required attribute(s) to the serialization constructor.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Secure serialization constructors.

RuleInstance.Name: Public/Protected Instance Field -> Do not declare in protected with link demand type
RuleInstance.Title: Secured types should not expose fields
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Externally visible type is protected with a System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.LinkDemand, has public field.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, types protected with System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.LinkDemand security action should not expose public fields because this action protects only properties and methods. If an assembly without all necessary permissions can grab a reference to an instance of a type protected with a System.Security.Permissions.SecurityAction.LinkDemand security action, the assembly can freely access all the public fields.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Secured types should not expose fields', CheckId CA2112
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change field modifier to Private (private in C#).
  • Create public property from the field.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Secured types should not expose fields.

RuleInstance.Name: Type -> Link demands require inheritance demands
RuleInstance.Title: Type link demands require inheritance demands
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Externally visible unsealed type is protected with a link demand, has an overridable method, and neither the type nor the method is protected with an inheritance demand.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, a type level SecurityAction.InheritanceDemand action should be used for any nonsealed type that is marked with a SecurityAction.LinkDemand action if the type has one or more Overridable (virtual in C#) methods. Alternatively, SecurityAction.InheritanceDemand action should be used for each virtual method. (The SecurityAction.InheritanceDemand action has no effect on nonvirtual members.)

Protecting an overridable member with a SecurityAction.LinkDemand action isn't sufficient if the type isn't sealed because malicious code might wait until a trusted assembly invokes (and indirectly JIT-compiles) the protected method and then instantiate an object that derives from the secured type but overrides the virtual member.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Type link demands require inheritance demands', CheckId CA2126
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Apply inheritance demands for the same permission as the type link demand to the type.
  • Apply inheritance demands for the same permission as the type link demand to the method.
  • Apply inheritance demands for the same permission as the method link demand to the type.
  • Apply inheritance demands for the same permission as the method link demand to the method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Type link demands require inheritance demands.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Secure asserts
RuleInstance.Title: Secure asserts
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The method asserts a permission and no security checks are performed on the caller member.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Because calling Assert removes the requirement that all code in the call chain must be granted permission to access the specified resource, it can open up security issues if used incorrectly or inappropriately. If you assert a permission without performing any checks on the caller, the caller might be able to indirectly execute code using your permissions.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Secure asserts', CheckId CA2106
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add a security demand (System.Security.PermissionSet(SecurityAction.LinkDemand)) to the method or type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Secure asserts.

RuleInstance.Name: Type, Method -> Security transparent code should not assert
RuleInstance.Title: Security transparent code should not assert
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Type or member is marked as SecurityTransparent or mixed transparent/critical is not granted sufficient permissions to assert permissions.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Any call to CodeAccessPermission.Assert from transparent code will cause a System.Security.SecurityException to be thrown at run time. Each transparent or mixed transparent/critical member which calls CodeAccessPermission.Assert should be marked with System.Security.SecurityCriticalAttribute attribute to avoid this issue.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Security transparent code should not assert', CheckId CA2128
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add System.Security.SecurityCriticalAttribute to the member
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Security transparent code should not assert.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Do not indirectly expose with link demands
RuleInstance.Title: Do not indirectly expose methods with link demands
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The member has a link demand and is called by the member that does not perform any security checks.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, you should not access members protected with a SecurityAction.LinkDemand security action, from members that are not protected with similar SecurityAction.LinkDemand security action.

Unlike the SecurityAction.Demand security action, which checks the permissions of all the callers in the stack, the SecurityAction.LinkDemand action check only the permissions of the immediate caller and does it only when the method is JIT-compiled (rather then at each method call). The behavior can improve performance but opens up a few security risks. A malicious client might wait until a trusted assembly invokes (and indirectly JIT-compiles) the protected method and then instantiate an object that derives from the secured type but overrides the virtual member.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not indirectly expose methods with link demands', CheckId CA2122
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add necessary attribute to the member
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not indirectly expose methods with link demands.

RuleInstance.Name: Type, Method -> Review suppress unmanaged code security usage
RuleInstance.Title: Review suppress unmanaged code security usage
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A public or protected type or member is marked with the System.Security.SuppressUnmanagedCodeSecurity attribute.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, you should avoid using the System.Security.SuppressUnmanagedCodeSecurity attribute at the type level in public or protected types as well as avoid applying the System.Security.SuppressUnmanagedCodeSecurity attribute to public and protected members.

By default, the .NET Framework makes a full Demand for methods that call unmanaged code through PInvoke or COM Interop services. If you mark the method (or its enclosing type) with the System.Security.SuppressUnmanagedCodeSecurity attribute, the .NET Framework makes a LinkDemand for the unmanaged code permission.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Review suppress unmanaged code security usage', CheckId CA2118
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Remove System.Security.SuppressUnmanagedCodeSecurityAttribute attribute from a type or member
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Review suppress unmanaged code security usage.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Should have identical link demands to base method
RuleInstance.Title: Override link demands should be identical to base
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Method in a public type implements an interface or overrides a method, and does not marked with the same SecurityAction.LinkDemand security action as the interface method or virtual method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, if you override a method marked with a SecurityAction.LinkDemand security action, the method in the derived type should be marked with the same SecurityAction.LinkDemand security action.

Unlike the SecurityAction.Demand security action, which checks the permissions of all the callers in the stack, the SecurityAction.LinkDemand action check only the permissions of the immediate caller and does it only when the method is JIT-compiled (rather then at each method call). The behavior can improve performance but opens up a few security risks. A malicious client might wait until a trusted assembly invokes (and indirectly JIT-compiles) the protected method and then instantiate an object that derives from the secured type but overrides the virtual member.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Override link demands should be identical to base', CheckId CA2123
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add necessary attribute to the method
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Override link demands should be identical to base.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> GetObjectData is not marked with SecurityPermissionAttribute
RuleInstance.Title: Secure GetObjectData overrides
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Method GetObjectData declared in the type that implements the System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable interface is not protected by security permission System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionAttribute.SerializationFormatter.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The GetObjectData method should be protected by demanding System.Security.Permissions.SecurityPermissionAttribute.SerializationFormatter permissions.

If the GetObjectData method is not protected by a security check for SerializationFormatter, it might result in a security risk because a malicious caller might serialize an instance obtained through a factory method exposed by a trusted assembly and then create a copy of it at a later time, or it might manufacture a stream of data containing arbitrary values and use it to create an invalid instance of the type.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Secure GetObjectData overrides', CheckId CA2110
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add attribute SecurityPermissionAttribute(SecurityAction.Demand, SerializationFormatter=true) to GetObjectData method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Secure GetObjectData overrides.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]

' This code will trigger the rule violation

Imports System.Runtime.Serialization

Public Class PersonalData
    Implements ISerializable
    
    <SecurityPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, ControlPrincipal:=True)> _
    Sub New (ByVal name As String)
      ...
    End Sub
		
	...
		
    ' Might result in a security risk!
    Public Sub GetObjectData(ByVal info As SerializationInfo, _
        ByVal context As StreamingContext) _
        Implements ISerializable.GetObjectData
		  
        ...
		  
    End Sub

End Class	

' This is the correct implementation
	
Imports System.Runtime.Serialization

Public Class PersonalData
    Implements ISerializable
    
    <SecurityPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, ControlPrincipal:=True)> _
    Sub New (ByVal name As String)
        ...
    End Sub
		
	...
		
    <SecurityPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, SerializationFormatter:=True)> _
    Public Sub GetObjectData(ByVal info As SerializationInfo, _
        ByVal context As StreamingContext) _
        Implements ISerializable.GetObjectData
		  
          ...
		  
    End Sub

End Class

[C#]

// This code will trigger the rule violation

using System.Runtime.Serialization;

public class PersonalData: ISerializable
{
    
    [SecurityPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, ControlPrincipal = true)]
    PersonalData (string name)
    {
      ...
    }
		
	...
		
    // Might result in a security risk!
    public void ISerializable.GetObjectData(SerializationInfo info,
        StreamingContext context)
    {
		  
        ...
		  
    }

}

// This is the correct implementation


using System.Runtime.Serialization;

public class PersonalData: ISerializable
{
    
    [SecurityPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, ControlPrincipal = true)]
    PersonalData (string name)
    {
      ...
    }
		
	...
		
    [SecurityPermission(SecurityAction.Demand, SerializationFormatter = true)]
    public void ISerializable.GetObjectData(SerializationInfo info,
        StreamingContext context)
    {
		  
        ...
		  
    }

}

RuleInstance.Name: Type -> Should not provide overridable implementation of internal interface
RuleInstance.Title: Seal methods that satisfy private interfaces
RuleInstance.Scope: Public
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Inheritable public type provides overridable method implementation of a Friend (internal in C#) interface.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
A public type that implements a method of an internal interface using the Overridable (virtual in C#) modifier allows the method to be overridden by a derived type that is outside the assembly. Such scenario can create the following security vulnerability: If a second type in the defining assembly calls the method and expects an internal-only contract, behavior might be compromised when, instead, the overridden method in the outside assembly is executed.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Seal methods that satisfy private interfaces', CheckId CA2119
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change type modifier to NotInheritable (sealed in C#).
  • Change type modifier to Friend (internal in C#).
  • Implement the method without Overridable modifier (virtual in C#).
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Seal methods that satisfy private interfaces.

RuleInstance.Name: Field -> Should not have read-only modifier if return type is mutable
RuleInstance.Title: Do not declare read only mutable reference types
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Externally visible read-only field has a return type that is mutable. A mutabe type is a type whose instance data can be modified.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
A mutabe type is a type whose instance data can be modified. Mutable type can change the value of an instance of the class. In the opposite, an immutable type cannot change its value once it is instantiated.

The System.Text.StringBuilder class, which contains members that can change the value of its instance, is an example of a mutable reference type. The System.String class, which can never change its value once it is instantiated, is an example of an immutable reference type.

The ReadOnly modifier (readonly in C#) on a reference type field prevents the field from being replaced by another instance of the reference type. But in the same time the field's instance data can be modified through the reference type.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Do not declare read only mutable reference types', CheckId CA2104
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Remove ReadOnly modifier from the field (readonly in C#).
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not declare read only mutable reference types.

RuleInstance.Name: Field -> Pointers should not be visible
RuleInstance.Title: Pointers should not be visible
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Externally visible field that has System.IntPtr or System.UIntPtr return type is not read-only.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
System.IntPtr and System.UIntPtr are platform-specific types that are used to represent a pointer or a handle for accessing unmanaged memory. Malicious code can change the value of the pointer, if a pointer is not read-only, private, or internal. That can potentially cause application or system failures or allow access to arbitrary locations in memory.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Pointers should not be visible', CheckId CA2111
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Make field read-only.
  • Change field modifier to internal (Friend in Visual Basic).
  • Change field modifier to private.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Pointers should not be visible.

RuleInstance.Name: Comment -> Should be spelled correctly
RuleInstance.Title: Comments should be spelled correctly
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Comment contains word, which is not recognized by the spelling checker library.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The rule was created to check spelling of comment strings. Spelling of each word in the comment is checked against the standard dictionary. If the word cannot be found in the standard dictionary the user has possibility to save it in the custom dictionary for further checks.

The English version of the spelling checker is only supported in present.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Change unrecognized word to the word from dictionary.
  • Add unrecognized word to the custom dictionary.
  • Change unrecognized word in comment text to the specified text.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Comments should be spelled correctly.

RuleInstance.Name: Code Element -> Should be spelled correctly
RuleInstance.Title: Identifiers should be spelled correctly
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.Targets: Namespace, Class, Interface, Delegate, Struct, Enumeration, Module, Type, Variable, LocalConstant, Method, Operator, Event, Property, Indexer, EnumerationItem, Parameter, Constant, Field, Member
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Code element name contains word, which is not recognized by the spelling checker library.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The rule was created to check spelling of the identifiers. Each new word in the identifier starts from capital letter. Spelling of each word in the identifiers is checked against the standard dictionary. If the word cannot be found in the standard dictionary the user has possibility to save it in the custom dictionary for further checks.

The English version of the spelling checker is only supported in present.

The rule provides the following auto-correct options:

  • Add unrecognized word to the custom dictionary.
  • Rename code element and its references to the specified name.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Identifiers should be spelled correctly.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Always close SQL resources
RuleInstance.Title: Always close SQL resources
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
Method opens System.Data.SqlClient.SqlConnection but Close or Dispose is not called

- OR -

Method performs call to ExecuteReader of System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand class but Close or Dispose of returned System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDataReader is not called.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
This rule detects situations when a resource leak is created by having a call to a method that opens an SqlConnection and not closing it with an appropriate method. The following is the list of methods considered for opening and closing the resources.

Resouce openers:
  • System.Data.SqlClient.SqlConnection.Open
  • System.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand.ExecuteReader
Resource closers:
  • System.Data.SqlClient.SqlConnection.Close
  • System.Data.SqlClient.SqlConnection.Dispose
  • System.ComponentModel.Component.Dispose
  • System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDataReader.Close
  • System.Data.SqlClient.SqlDataReader.Dispose
  • System.IDisposable.Dispose
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add method call that closes SQL resource.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Always close SQL resources.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Always close standard IO streams
RuleInstance.Title: Always close standard IO streams
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
Method opens standard IO Stream but not closes or disposes it.

- OR -

Method opens standard Reader but not closes or disposes it.

- OR -

Method opens standard Witer but not closes or disposes it.

- OR -

Method opens standard File but not closes or disposes it.

- OR -

Method opens standard Security.Cryptography.CryptoStream but not closes or disposes it.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
This rule detects situations when a resource leak is created by having a call to a method that opens an I/O Stream and not closing it with an appropriate method. The following is the list of classes that this rule handles while detecting resources leaks.
  • System.CodeDom.Compiler.IndentedTextWriter
  • System.IO.BinaryReader
  • System.IO.BinaryWriter
  • System.IO.BufferedStream
  • System.IO.FileInfo (factory for producing wrappers)
  • System.IO.File (factory for producing wrappers)
  • System.IO.StreamReader
  • System.IO.StreamWriter
  • System.Resources.ResourceReader
  • System.Resources.ResourceSet
  • System.Resources.ResourceWriter
  • System.Resources.ResXResourceReader
  • System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter
  • System.Xml.XmlTextReader
  • System.Xml.XmlTextWriter
  • System.Xml.XmlValidatingReader
  • Security.Cryptography.CryptoStream
Each of these classes supports methods such as Create, Open, OpenRead, etc. which will be considered to open the resource. A corresponding call to a clsoing method such as Close or Dispose is expected to be present along every execution path before the variable that holds a reference to the opened resource goes out of scope.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Add method call that closes IO stream.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Always close standard IO streams.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Always provide names for threads
RuleInstance.Title: Always provide names for threads

RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: It is very difficult to work with threads without names during debugging.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription: This reports a violation whenever the call to the constructor of Thread is not immediately followed by an assignment to the Name property of the threads.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Avoid control statements with empty bodies
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid control statements with empty bodies
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
A conditional statement that is immediately followed by a closing statement (e.g. a semicolon) is usually a typo.

- OR -

Missing out or improper handling important conditions that can even cause security holes.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription: This rule identifies if, for, while, do while, else and switch statements with empty bodies. An error is reported for each occurrence.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Fill the empty body control statement manually.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid control statements with empty bodies.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Avoid empty
RuleInstance.Title: Avoid empty methods
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: Placeholder empty methods are not filled with a code which can lead to bugs or errors in application behaviour.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
This rule identifies code that declares a method with an empty body. An error is reported for each occurrence.

This rule does not apply for abstract, virtual, or override methods to reserve the use of polymorphism.

Prevents missing out implementation of important methods such as logging methods or methods that need to take important actions under abnormal cirucmstances, which are important for security.

During development empty methods often get introduced as place-holders for something to be implemented at a later time. For example, we could have a method that is supposed to log some error condition, but the developer decided to work on the normal cases first. These methods should get filled in before the product is released. To avoid oversights of this nature, it is best to ensure that there are no empty methods unless explicitly allowed (possibly via suppression of the violation).
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Comment out the empty method.
  • Remove the empty method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Avoid empty methods.

RuleInstance.Title: Avoid use of 'new' keyword for hiding methods

RuleInstance.Name: Custom Serialization -> Type -> Call base class methods on ISerializable types
RuleInstance.Title: Call base class methods on ISerializable types
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
Type derives from a type that implements the System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable interface, implements System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable.GetObjectData method but does not call the GetObjectData(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo, System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext) method of the base type.

Or

Type derives from a type that implements the System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable interface, implements the serialization constructor with the (System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo, System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext) parameter signature, but does not call the serialization constructor of the base type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
Implementing System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable involves implementing the GetObjectData method and a special constructor that is used when the object is deserialized. Derived classes should call the GetObjectData method and serialization constructor of the base object if the latter implements System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable. In opposite case, the type will not be serialized and de-serialized correctly. But if the derived type does not introduces any new fields, then the type does not need to implement the GetObjectData method and special serialization constructor. It does not need to call the base type equivalents as well.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Call base class methods on ISerializable types', CheckId CA2236
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Find method System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable.GetObjectData and insert a GetObjectData(System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo, System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext) call at the beginning or at the end of the method.
  • Find constructor with the (System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationInfo, System.Runtime.Serialization.StreamingContext) parameter signature and insert a call of the base type serialization constructor at the beginning of the constructor.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Call base class methods on ISerializable types.

RuleInstance.Name: Method -> Close database connections in 'finally' block
RuleInstance.Title: Close database connections in 'finally' block
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any

RuleInstance.Name: Calls without local implementation -> Should not be prefixed with the 'base.' ('MyBase.' in Visual Basic)
RuleInstance.Title: Do not prefix calls with 'base' ('MyBase' in Visual Basic) unless local implementation exists
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The call to the method is unnecessarily prefixed with base (MyBase in Visual Basic) keyword.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription: The base (MyBase in Visual Basic) keyword is used to access members of the base class from within a derived class. The call to the method should only use the base keyword if the item is declared virtual (Overridable in Visual Basic) in the base class and an override is defined in the local class, i.e. if a method on the base class has been overridden by another method.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Replace base (MyBase in Visual Basic) keyword with this (Me in Visual Basic) keyword on the method call.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Do not prefix calls with 'base' ('MyBase' in Visual Basic) unless local implementation exists.

RuleInstance.Name: Property -> Lock both when either set or get is locked
RuleInstance.Title: Lock both when either set or get is locked for a property
RuleInstance.Scope: New, Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Extern, Unsafe, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Any
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem:
Property has both get and set methods and only one of the methods uses a lock and the other does not

- OR -

Property has both get and set methods and both of them use lock, but lock on different objects
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription: If one of the methods in a property requires a lock, then it is very likely that the other one also needs it. Not locking can lead to issues that are very hard to detect and debug since the issues are usually not easy to reproduce.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Lock both get and set accessors on the same object for the property.

RuleInstance.Name: Dispose -> Field -> Disposable fields should be disposed
RuleInstance.Title: Disposable fields should be disposed
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: A type implements System.IDisposable interface and declares field, which is of type that implements System.IDisposable as well, but the Dispose method of the declaring type does not call the Dispose method of this field.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
The Dispose method of the type, which implements System.IDisposable interface, should release all the resources that it owns. The Dispose method of the type should call the Dispose method for each field that hold a reference to a disposable object.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Disposable fields should be disposed', CheckId CA2213
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Find method Dispose(disposing) and insert a Dispose() call at the end of the dispose snippet in the code path where disposing is True.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Disposable fields should be disposed.

According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, if a type has System.IntPtr, System.UIntPtr, or System.Runtime.InteropServices.HandleRef fields, than it most likely stores pointers to unmanaged resources and therefore.

RuleInstance.Name: Dispose -> Method -> Should call base class dispose
RuleInstance.Title: Dispose methods should call base class dispose

RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The type derives from a type that implements the System.IDisposable interface, implements Dispose method, but does not call the Dispose method of the base type.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, if the type derives from a type that implements the System.IDisposable interface, it must call the Dispose method of the base type from within its own implemented Dispose method.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Dispose methods should call base class dispose', CheckId CA2215

RuleInstance.Name: Finalize -> Method -> Should be protected
RuleInstance.Title: Finalizers should be protected
RuleInstance.Scope: Public, Protected, Internal, ProtectedInternal, Private, Abstract, Sealed, Static, Readonly, Virtual, Override, Unsafe, SpecialName, Literal, Const, Volatile, WriteOnly, WithEvents, Default
RuleInstance.HelpRuleProblem: The type implements a finalizer that does not have protected modifier.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleDescription:
According to Microsoft .NET Framework guidelines, types that implement finalizer must use protected modifier. This rule is enforced by the C# and Visual Basic compilers.

This rule is similar to FxCop rule 'Finalizers should be protected', CheckId CA2221
RuleInstance.HelpRuleCorrectingViolations:
The rule provides the following auto-correct options:
  • Find finalizer and change its modifier to protected.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleInstances:
Instances of this rule in the built-in profile:
  • Finalizers should be protected.
RuleInstance.HelpRuleExample:
The following examples show code that triggers the rule violation as well as the correct implementation.

[Visual Basic]


' This code will trigger the rule violation

  Public Class SampleType
    Implements IDisposable

    Protected disposed As Boolean = False
    
    ...
    
    Protected Overridable Sub Dispose(ByVal disposing As Boolean)
      If Not Me.disposed Then
        If disposing Then
        
          ...
          
        End If
        
        ' Release unmanaged resources
        ...
        
        Me.disposed = True

      End If
    End Sub

    Public Sub Dispose() Implements IDisposable.Dispose
      Dispose(True)
      GC.SuppressFinalize(Me)
    End Sub
    
    Overrides Sub Finalize()
      Try
        Dispose(False)
      Catch
        ' Deal with errors or just ignore them
      Finally
        ' Invoke the base object's Finalize method
        MyBase.Finalize()
      End Try
    End Sub
    
  End Class


' This is the correct implementation

  Public Class SampleType
    Implements IDisposable

    Protected disposed As Boolean = False
    
    ...
    
    Protected Overridable Sub Dispose(ByVal disposing As Boolean)
      If Not Me.disposed Then
        If disposing Then
        
          ...
          
        End If
        
        ' Release unmanaged resources
        ...
        
        Me.disposed = True

      End If
    End Sub

    Public Sub Dispose() Implements IDisposable.Dispose
      Dispose(True)
      GC.SuppressFinalize(Me)
    End Sub
    
    Protected Overrides Sub Finalize()
      Try
        Dispose(False)
      Catch
        ' Deal with errors or just ignore them
      Finally
        ' Invoke the base object's Finalize method
        MyBase.Finalize()
      End Try
    End Sub
    
  End Class

' This is the correct implementation
